headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Broadcom Limited First Quarter Fiscal Year 2017 Financial Results Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Ashish Saran, Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext: Welcome to Broadcom Limited First Quarter Fiscal Year 2017 Financial Results Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Ashish Saran, Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator, and good afternoon, everyone. Joining me today are Hock Tan, President and CEO; and Tom Krause, Chief Financial Officer of Broadcom Limited.After market close today, Broadcom distributed a press release and financial tables describi
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and good afternoon, everyone. Joining me today are Hock Tan, President and CEO; and Tom Krause, Chief Financial Officer of Broadcom Limited.
After market close today, Broadcom distributed a press release and financial tables describing our financial performance for the first quarter of fiscal year 2017. If you did not receive a copy, you may obtain the information from the Investors section of Broadcom's website at www.broadcom.com. This conference call is being webcast live, and a recording will be available via telephone playback for 1 week. It will also be archived in the Investors section of our website at broadcom.com.
During the prepared comments section of this call, Hock and Tom will be providing details of our first quarter of fiscal year 2017 results, background to our second quarter fiscal year 2017 outlook and some commentary regarding the business environment. We will take questions after the end of our prepared comments.
In addition to U.S. GAAP reporting, Broadcom reports certain financial measures on a non-GAAP basis. A reconciliation between GAAP and non-GAAP measures is included in the tables attached to today's press release. Comments made during today's call will primarily refer to our non-GAAP financial results. Please refer to our press release today and our recent filings with the SEC for information on specific risk factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statements made on this call.
At this time, I would like to turn like to turn the call over to Hock Tan. Hock?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ashish. Good afternoon, everyone. Well, we delivered strong financial results for the first quarter, with revenue of $4.15 billion and gross margin at 62.4%, both at the very top end of our guidance. Earnings per share of $3.63 grew by 5% seque
componenttext:
Thank you, Ashish. Good afternoon, everyone. Well, we delivered strong financial results for the first quarter, with revenue of $4.15 billion and gross margin at 62.4%, both at the very top end of our guidance. Earnings per share of $3.63 grew by 5% sequentially, while net revenue was essentially flat. Revenue was better-than-expected in all 4 segments. The benefits we achieved through business diversification clearly came through this quarter, with growth in wired, enterprise storage and industrial completely offsetting the typical negative seasonality from wireless. The integration of classic Broadcom has gone very well and is now mostly complete. We remain focused on driving financial performance towards our long-term operating margin and free cash flow targets.
Let me now turn to a discussion of our segment results, starting with wired, our largest segment. In the first quarter, wired revenue came in at $2.09 billion better-than-expected and represented 50% of our total revenue. Revenue for this segment was up slightly on a sequential basis. We benefited from strong demand for our Ethernet switching and routing product from cloud data center operators. This growth was partially offset by the continuing seasonal decline in demand for our broadband carrier access and set-top box products, which we expect would bottom in this first quarter.
Turning to the second fiscal quarter. We forecast wired revenue to experience sequential growth a little bit stronger than we what we saw in the prior quarter. We expect the momentum from cloud data center demand to sustain, and expect the seasonal increase in demand for our broadband access and set-top box products.
Now moving on to wireless. In the first quarter, wireless revenue came in at about $1.18 billion, better-than-expected, and the wireless segment represented 28% of our total revenue. Revenue for this segment was down 13% sequentially, driven by the expected seasonal decline in demand from a major North American customer.
Turning now to our projection for the second quarter of fiscal '17. We expect to hit the bottom of the annual product cycle transition at a major North American customer. However, we expect to offset the significant portion of this decline in wireless from a ramp of the next-generation phone and our large Korean smartphone customer. This phone comes with an increase in Broadcom's RF and WiFi connectivity content. As a result, we expect our wireless revenue in the second quarter of fiscal '17 to be still sequentially down but in the high single digits, better than the most difficult double-digit declines we have experienced in prior years.
Let me now turn to enterprise storage, which continues to be strong. In the first quarter, enterprise storage revenue came in at $707 million, and this segment represented 17% of our total revenue. Segment revenue grew 26% sequentially, gaining better than expected, driven by stronger shipment of SaaS, RAID and Fibre Channel products. As we foresaw, our hard disk drive and custom solid-state drive controllers also had a very strong quarter. And looking into the second quarter, however, we believe this resurgence of enterprise storage has to taper off and hence flatten out. Having said that, backlog for enterprise storage products continues up to today to be very strong. But we foresaw -- but we foresee seasonality to start slowing demand in the third quarter if not in this -- late in the second quarter.
Finally, turning to our last segment, industrial. In the first quarter, industrial revenue grew -- came in at $180 million, up 11% sequentially, better-than-expected, as we rebuild depleted channel inventory, consistent with stronger product refits [ph]. The industrial segment represented 5% of our total revenue. And as we look into the second quarter, we are anticipating industrial activity to continue to improve seasonally and accordingly, we are expecting industrial segment revenue to increase by high single digits sequentially.
With all that, to sum up -- to simply sum up, this first quarter was strong with revenue flat from the seasonally high fourth quarter of the preceding year. As we now look into the second quarter, we expect the demand environment for our products to continue to be very healthy and our outlook for this quarter's revenue to be virtually flat to that of the prior quarter. It is becoming evident that our broader and more diversified product portfolio has largely mitigated seasonal impacts to consolidated revenue during the first half of the year. This is certainly an intrinsic goal of our business model, just that we did not expect to achieve this so soon. The integration of classic Broadcom is clearly going well, and we continue to invest across all our franchise products. We are sustaining our technology leadership and our products are very well received by our customers.
Our revenue trajectory from the first half of fiscal 2017 could possibly extend into the second half. Nonetheless, we do not expect that the approximate 15% level of year-on-year growth we are guiding for the second quarter to really be sustainable in the long term. Our long-term operating model will continue to assume mid-single-digit annual revenue growth for the consolidated business.
With that, let me now turn the call over to Tom for a more detailed review of our first quarter fiscal 2017 financials.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Hock, and good afternoon, everyone. My comments today will focus primarily on our non-GAAP results from continuing operations, unless otherwise specifically noted. A reconciliation of our GAAP and non-GAAP data is included in with the earnings
componenttext:
Thank you, Hock, and good afternoon, everyone. My comments today will focus primarily on our non-GAAP results from continuing operations, unless otherwise specifically noted. A reconciliation of our GAAP and non-GAAP data is included in with the earnings release issued today and is also available on our website at broadcom.com.
Let me first start off by saying that we are very pleased with the execution this quarter, and specifically the progress we've made towards our long-term target model, which remains an operating margin target of 45% of net revenue and a free cash flow margin above 35% of net revenue. Further, what Hock was saying, we also believe that we can achieve these long-term operating targets based on the sustainable long-term revenue growth rate of mid-single digits.
Now let me review the Q1 results. Revenue for the first quarter came in at $4.15 billion, approximately flat sequentially. Foxconn was a greater than 10% direct customer in the first fiscal [ph] quarter. Our first quarter gross margin from continuing operations was 62.4%, about 90 basis points above the midpoint of guidance primarily due to revenue at the top end of guidance and a slightly better product mix. This quarter's gross margin also benefited from the impact of approximately $60 million of revenue related to the assignment of certain manufacturing rights to a customer in our wired segment which is included in our original guidance.
Turning to our operating expenses. R&D expenses were $664 million and SG&A expenses were $120 million. This resulted in total operating expenses for the first quarter of $784 million or 18.9% of net revenue. As Hock mentioned, we have now largely completed the integration of classic Broadcom, and I would reiterate that we feel comfortable at this level of operating expenses relative to net revenue.
Operating income from continuing operations for the quarter was $1.8 billion and represented 43.5% of net revenue. Provision for taxes came in at $77 million, slightly above our guidance. This is primarily due to higher-than-expected net income, first quarter interest expense of $110 million and other income that was $8 million. First quarter net income was $1.63 billion and earnings per diluted share were $3.63. Our share-based compensation expense in the first quarter was $201 million.
Moving on to the balance sheet. Our day sales outstanding were 43 days, a decrease of 5 days from the prior quarter due to better linearity of revenue in the quarter. Our inventory ended at $1.34 billion, a decrease of $64 million from the beginning of the quarter. We generated $1.35 billion in operational cash flow, which reflected the impact of approximately $313 million for annual employee bonus payments for fiscal year 2016 and approximately $80 million of cash expended on classic Broadcom restructuring integration activities, including discontinued operations.
I'm very pleased that in the first quarter, the business already demonstrated the ability to generate free cash flow close to our long-term target model of 35%, while free cash flow in the first quarter was $1 billion approximately, or only 25% of net revenue. This does include, I want to highlight, the impact from the annual employee cash bonus payment as well as cash restructuring expenses and capital expenditures, that as we discussed before, running higher than our long-term targets. Looking forward, we expect classic Broadcom-related restructuring expenses to continue to decrease as we finish this integration.
Capital expenditure in the first quarter was $325 million or 7.8% of net revenue. However, we expect long-term CapEx largely as a fabless semiconductor company to run at about 3% of net revenue, consistent with that fabless business model. As a reminder, for full fiscal year 2017, we expect CapEx to run at an elevated level of approximately $1.2 billion. This includes about $500 million towards campus construction, primarily at our Irvine, San Jose locations and about $200 million towards purchasing of test equipment for consignment at our CMs. A total of $431 million in cash was spent on company dividend and partnership distribution payments in the first quarter. We ended the first quarter with a cash balance of approximately $3.5 billion.
Now let me turn to non-GAAP guidance for the second quarter of fiscal year 2017. This guidance reflects our current assessment of business conditions, and we do not intend to update this guidance. This guidance is from results from continuing operations only.
Net revenue is expected to be $4.1 billion, plus or minus $75 million. Gross margin is expected to be 62% plus or minus 1 percentage point. Operating expenses are estimated to be approximately $789 million. Tax provision is forecasted to be approximately $74 million. Net interest expense and other is expected to be approximately $106 million. The diluted share count forecast is for 452 million shares. Share-based compensation expense will be approximately $223 million. CapEx will be approximately $290 million. As you'll have seen, our board has declared a dividend of $1.02 per share to be paid later in the second fiscal quarter.
We're also looking forward to completing the acquisition of Brocade, which is proceeding as planned, and we personally expect to close this transaction in our third quarter of fiscal 2017. I'm pleased that we're able to reach an agreement with ARRIS earlier this quarter for the sale of Brocade's network EDGE business for $800 million in cash, plus the additional cost of unvested employee stock -- awards. Following Brocade's recent results, we continue to feel very comfortable that Brocade's Fibre Channel sand switching business, the key business that we are focused on, will generate approximately $900 million of EBITDA in fiscal 2018. 
That concludes my prepared remarks. Operator, please open the call for questions.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Ross Seymore with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Ross Seymore with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: I guess, Hock, the first question's on the wireless side. It's good to see the content rising at other customers besides your big North American customer. Can you just talk a little bit more detail about what's driving that content up? Is there anything u
componenttext: I guess, Hock, the first question's on the wireless side. It's good to see the content rising at other customers besides your big North American customer. Can you just talk a little bit more detail about what's driving that content up? Is there anything unique? Or is it basically the same goodness that you've seen in the North America side? And any more color about that goodness continuing in the North America side into the second half this year would also be helpful.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ross, thanks for the question. Yes, in fact, it's a phenomenon we have been indicating to you guys for the last several years, which is over the medium term -- long term, I would say, our strength -- our franchise in cellular and our RF, in cellular
componenttext: Yes, Ross, thanks for the question. Yes, in fact, it's a phenomenon we have been indicating to you guys for the last several years, which is over the medium term -- long term, I would say, our strength -- our franchise in cellular and our RF, in cellular and the -- the front end cellular and envelope, which includes -- and -- and all the circuitry and component that goes in front of the transceiver and the handset for cellular, that's one area. And the other area is WiFi, Bluetooth connectivity. Those 2 functionalities, those 2 features in phones continue to evolve and with each generation. And as each generation evolves, one is involves in the case of RF cellular is twofold. One is basically more band as we progressed -- as more and more countries globally progress into 4G and eventually even before the beyond that. More and more bands, spectral bandwidths get pulled into the fold. And number of SKUs of phones get less and less for any major OEM manufacturer simply because of complexity of these phones. And so because more band that requires more filters, more components like power amplifiers, low-noise amplifiers and because of that necessary content increases. I should also add the difficulty of engineering those products increase fairly exponentially, which therefore drives towards better and better content for us into those very high-end flagship smartphones. In the case of wireless connectivity, the same phenomenon is happening and particularly driven on bandwidth, on -- throughput as we move from what used to be much lower bandwidth in WiFi to today's AC, as we move from single-user to multiple users and as we move next-generation from AC into AX and further. Obviously, difficulty of doing those products in smartphones becomes correspondingly more difficult. Content increases and we benefit from basically content increase. It's a normal phenomenon and we expect to see that continuing into the near -- into the medium term.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Great. That's helpful. I guess for my one follow-up, both you and Tom, Hock, mentioned about the 15% growth not being your long-term assumption. Just wondering why you're bringing that up. Is there something that you're seeing now that gives you pause tha
componenttext: Great. That's helpful. I guess for my one follow-up, both you and Tom, Hock, mentioned about the 15% growth not being your long-term assumption. Just wondering why you're bringing that up. Is there something that you're seeing now that gives you pause that things are going to slow down? Or is this just kind of a reminder that the level we are now is not the base assumption in your business model?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think the fairest way to answer that is we have articulated last fiscal year very carefully, and even a year ago when we acquired Broadcom, as long as a year ago, that we have a scale and we have a diversification of product portfolio. Our long-term mod
componenttext: I think the fairest way to answer that is we have articulated last fiscal year very carefully, and even a year ago when we acquired Broadcom, as long as a year ago, that we have a scale and we have a diversification of product portfolio. Our long-term model, our 5 years, 10 years is a compounded annual growth of 5%. Not every year necessarily but long term, 5%. And why do we feel the need to mention it is obviously, you saw the numbers that we were guiding for Q2 on the top line, and it's showing 15% year-on-year from a year ago. That's just 1 quarter, and obviously just 1 fiscal year, one point in time. So we felt it necessary to just mention it that do not just take it and extrapolate it to say that we have moved away from our broad model or guidance of 5% compounded annual growth in the long term to a 15%. Far from it.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ross, I might just add, I also want to reiterate that we don't believe we need to have this accelerated revenue growth to hit our financial targets, which we remain very focused on. Specifically the free cash flow mark of 35%. We were very comfortabl
componenttext: Yes, Ross, I might just add, I also want to reiterate that we don't believe we need to have this accelerated revenue growth to hit our financial targets, which we remain very focused on. Specifically the free cash flow mark of 35%. We were very comfortable achieving those results based on a more normalized, long-term -- of mid-single digits.

Just curious between content and newness, what are you seeing with that -- your 2 large customers in terms of the seasonality and the timing of ramp, magnitude versus the content gains you're seeing?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017

componenttext: To be -- I don't have specific data between to be [indiscernible] scale up accurately between units in content. But on the cusp, my sense is it's largely content.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then you mentioned strength in switching. I was curious -- I, know obviously you don't want to guide for the full year. I was just curious, you talked about some business softness in second half, there's obviously big upgrade cycles like
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then you mentioned strength in switching. I was curious -- I, know obviously you don't want to guide for the full year. I was just curious, you talked about some business softness in second half, there's obviously big upgrade cycles like 2500G. Just curious as your perspective as you look at the rest of the year, the trajectory of the switch business.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: That's a very interesting question. And on the switching side, which is a subset, obviously, of our wired segment, which is our largest segment. But just if you look at our switching and routing side, if I were to put them together, which is really data c
componenttext: That's a very interesting question. And on the switching side, which is a subset, obviously, of our wired segment, which is our largest segment. But just if you look at our switching and routing side, if I were to put them together, which is really data center, networking business. We continue to see strength through the rest of the year. We see -- a big part of that strength we see is simply because off a very strong data center demand, data center buildup by the cloud operators. We're seeing that now. And I suspect that phenomenon will still continue, particularly when we start to ramp-up a new generation with high bandwidth of Tomahawks and Tridents. And as we go later part of the year of our DMX router and aggregation switches. So we see that in this momentum to be fairly good based on demand -- intrinsic demand out there in data center expansion especially into the cloud of but also the fact that we are launching a few very key new products in this year. Okay?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Harlan Sur with JP Morgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Harlan Sur with JP Morgan.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: It's great to see the diversity in the business playing out here. On the strong growth in the storage business, I'm assuming some of this is your SSD product line. I believe you guys are sup ploying enterprise SSD consumers into the top 2 enterprise and c
componenttext: It's great to see the diversity in the business playing out here. On the strong growth in the storage business, I'm assuming some of this is your SSD product line. I believe you guys are sup ploying enterprise SSD consumers into the top 2 enterprise and cloud SSD suppliers. And I think your top customer here just grew their enterprise SSD business I think 20% sequentially and 20% year-over-year in the December quarter. Wondering if you guys have seen similar growth trends? And do you expect double-digit growth in this SSD segment for the full year.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: I'll be direct. Our visibility in SSDs are not as good as perhaps our customer's are. And a big part of it is -- there are 3 parts to our enterprise storage, 3 broad parts. One is very related to storage server connectivity that's the rate starts. And som
componenttext: I'll be direct. Our visibility in SSDs are not as good as perhaps our customer's are. And a big part of it is -- there are 3 parts to our enterprise storage, 3 broad parts. One is very related to storage server connectivity that's the rate starts. And sometimes, the Fibre Channel host the -- side of it rate. And then there is the component we ship into hard disk drives. And hard disk drive has experience as you well know, a strong surge over the next several months probably because flash have been in short supply. And the last -- and the smallest part of our business, enterprise storage, is really related to enterprise flash controllers for SSD. And this is really a small part. So we don't get that broad visibility into this SSD market as a lot of other people would. But you're right. Right now, it's very, very strong, especially in SaaS.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Great. And then off of the success of Tomahawk and I also hear that your prior generation, Trident, is still very strong as well, and the team is ramping into this upgrade cycle. But you started sampling Tomahawk 2, I think it was second half of last year
componenttext: Great. And then off of the success of Tomahawk and I also hear that your prior generation, Trident, is still very strong as well, and the team is ramping into this upgrade cycle. But you started sampling Tomahawk 2, I think it was second half of last year. Can you give us an update on the qualification, customer feedback? And when should we see the adoption curve for T2 saturating to going to ramp? Is that going to be kind of 2018 time frame?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: For very competitive reasons, I really hate to give you specifics year. Suffice it to say, it's very well received. We have a lot of momentum on our entire switch portfolio. And by the way, as Tomahawk doesn't fully replace Trident. Trident is used in a d
componenttext: For very competitive reasons, I really hate to give you specifics year. Suffice it to say, it's very well received. We have a lot of momentum on our entire switch portfolio. And by the way, as Tomahawk doesn't fully replace Trident. Trident is used in a different segment versus Tomahawk. And both are going very well. As the Jericho products, which are more aggregation switching and routing. So -- but broadly, our portfolio of -- from high-end down to low range -- in the low-end range of switching and campus switching [indiscernible] those are all going very well. And I suspect it's all largely due to the strength in data center spending that still we see continue, particularly more recently since we have very strong conversion of enterprises into the cloud.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from William Stein, SunTrust.
componenttext: Your next question comes from William Stein, SunTrust.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: I wanted to address the free cash flow margin trajectory. Tom, I think you referred to some of his in your prepared remarks but I'd like you to maybe highlight what, aside from the restructuring expenses that are still being paid and the temporarily highe
componenttext: I wanted to address the free cash flow margin trajectory. Tom, I think you referred to some of his in your prepared remarks but I'd like you to maybe highlight what, aside from the restructuring expenses that are still being paid and the temporarily higher CapEx that you're experiencing. What are the other drivers to get you to do 35% free cash flow margin? And what sort of timing should we think about the that?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good question. I might think that sort of our prepared remarks. If you look at where we are from an operating margin perspective, if you look at the fact that we restructured the balance sheet around now fixed-rate debt. If you look at our sustainable tax
componenttext: Good question. I might think that sort of our prepared remarks. If you look at where we are from an operating margin perspective, if you look at the fact that we restructured the balance sheet around now fixed-rate debt. If you look at our sustainable tax rate of 4.5% and then cash taxes of approximately $100 million a quarter, and you take out the restructuring costs, which are bleeding off here pretty quickly, you take out the onetime campus initiative, the onetime test remission this year sort of play itself out here over the next couple of quarters, frankly, we're largely there. And that's part of the real take away. And of course, that doesn't take into account what we would expect to be second half seasonally uptrends from a revenue perspective.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. Appreciate it. Maybe one more, something that came up last quarter was the changing allocate capital allocation strategy. Maybe you can start of highlight for us your plans on the M&A front from here despite the higher dividend, the signif
componenttext: That's helpful. Appreciate it. Maybe one more, something that came up last quarter was the changing allocate capital allocation strategy. Maybe you can start of highlight for us your plans on the M&A front from here despite the higher dividend, the significantly higher your free cash flow that you're going to be generating I guess after these temporary expenses falloff would seem to me to continue to support a good M&A pipeline. Maybe you can characterize that for us, please?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, there's no real update there other than we outlined very clearly that we're going to continue to drive giving back 50% of free cash flows to investors through dividends, which, of course, at these levels would imply that we're going to have t
componenttext: Yes, I mean, there's no real update there other than we outlined very clearly that we're going to continue to drive giving back 50% of free cash flows to investors through dividends, which, of course, at these levels would imply that we're going to have the ability to continue to increase the dividend pretty meaningfully here over the next couple of years certainly. Beyond that, we've used M&A to drive returns, obviously, over the last several years pretty effectively. We continue to see opportunities to do that. Brocade is the latest example of our being able to put capital to work in an interesting opportunity to drive better returns than our alternative so we're going to continue to do that. But given our scale, we have the opportunity to do that mostly off of the balance sheet, particularly with robust opportunities that arise.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Craig Hettenbach with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Craig Hettenbach with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: This is Vinayak calling for Craig. So wonder on carrier aggregation like this is one of the key growth drivers for you RF business. Hock, can you provide us an update on the trends you're seeing by geography for that? And what that means for your portfoli
componenttext: This is Vinayak calling for Craig. So wonder on carrier aggregation like this is one of the key growth drivers for you RF business. Hock, can you provide us an update on the trends you're seeing by geography for that? And what that means for your portfolio?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. Carrier aggregation, as you well know, is the phenomenon of especially benefiting operators who have multiple spectral bandwidths, not necessary 1 but multiple. And in the of interest of reducing CapEx in infrastructure is the phenomenon of enabling
componenttext: Okay. Carrier aggregation, as you well know, is the phenomenon of especially benefiting operators who have multiple spectral bandwidths, not necessary 1 but multiple. And in the of interest of reducing CapEx in infrastructure is the phenomenon of enabling those bandwidth to combined together into one, which creates much more capacity throughput. And so not only an infrastructure that it goes into the fold. And we are probably one of the leading enablers in the form of making that happen, simply because not just architectural design of the cellular RF -- but also the fact that FBAR filters, which RFR format better performing and more integral and be able to integrate -- be integrated into modules to allow that maxing and de-maxing of those separate spectral bands. And that's happening. It started very aggressively as you see in China continuing to be very much so in China. It's also happening very aggressively in the U.S. Those are the 2 biggest geographies, where a lot of that is happening, started with downlink last year, I think, and is now moving on to uplinking, not just downlinking, which, of course, then are the recent ways to help create -- not the only reason but one of the reasons creating increased content in our cellular RF demand. So it's great for us, and we see the phenomenon continuing to grow and expand into other regions of the world.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful. And for my follow-up, I wanted to touch on gross margin. Pretty good performance in gross margins during the quarter and the guidance. But I was thinking about how should we think about gross margins for here? And if you can outlin
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And for my follow-up, I wanted to touch on gross margin. Pretty good performance in gross margins during the quarter and the guidance. But I was thinking about how should we think about gross margins for here? And if you can outline like what are the top 2 drivers of gross margin expansion as you look out towards the rest of fiscal 2017?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, it's a very interesting point. And as we -- if you look back to a year ago when we just closed the Broadcom transaction, every quarter since then we have been able to expand our gross margin in the range of roughly 40, 50 basis points sequenti
componenttext: Okay. Well, it's a very interesting point. And as we -- if you look back to a year ago when we just closed the Broadcom transaction, every quarter since then we have been able to expand our gross margin in the range of roughly 40, 50 basis points sequentially. A big part of it is as we settle down the portfolio, as we start to get the benefit of larger scale in purchasing materials and as specific actions like taking -- basically bringing testing very much in-house and consigning testers to contract manufacturers to save up leasing has signed for our huge volume in semiconductor chips. All those various actions, a large -- a big part of this expansion of gross margin comes from a scale and ability to leverage on the scale in direct materials. It also helps that our product margin, as we move from one generation to another, keeps getting richer in terms of the mix. So that's a combination of these 2 things. And in terms of where would it go from here, frankly, I don't know. Best indicator is to probably look at history.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Stacy Rasgon from Bernstein Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Stacy Rasgon from Bernstein Research.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: For my first one, you've talked a lot about the free cash flow margins but I wanted to dig a little bit on the payout ratio. You're paying out right now about a little over 30%. Target is 50%. Should we think about that sort of that level going up to 50%
componenttext: For my first one, you've talked a lot about the free cash flow margins but I wanted to dig a little bit on the payout ratio. You're paying out right now about a little over 30%. Target is 50%. Should we think about that sort of that level going up to 50% in line with the margins going up to 35% or more like how should trajectory of reaching your target on the payout ratio? That seems like something that's more in your control maybe been quicker than the margins themselves.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well they kind of go hand-in-hand, Stacy. I think what we're going to do and what we've articulated in the past is we're going into the end of the fiscal year, we're going to look back at the free cash flow trajectory in those margins over the course of t
componenttext: Well they kind of go hand-in-hand, Stacy. I think what we're going to do and what we've articulated in the past is we're going into the end of the fiscal year, we're going to look back at the free cash flow trajectory in those margins over the course of that previous year. We're going to look at the business obviously, we're very focused on sustainability. And then we're going to pay out 50%. And so what you're seeing is the general trajectory improving from where we exited last year to where we are here exiting Q1 and guiding Q2. And you're right, consistent with that policy is that we get to the end of the year, if we're able to achieve expectations then we're going to have -- perhaps be in a position to raise the dividend consistent with getting back the 50% on an LTM basis.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's hopeful. And for my follow-up, also wanted to dig in the gross margins a little bit. You talked a little bit about the drivers but I heard you say earlier that you're sort of comfortable with a level of OpEx spending as a percentage of reve
componenttext: Got it. That's hopeful. And for my follow-up, also wanted to dig in the gross margins a little bit. You talked a little bit about the drivers but I heard you say earlier that you're sort of comfortable with a level of OpEx spending as a percentage of revenue which implies that the operating margin improvement for the model for here comes from gross margins but it's not that much. It's only about, oh, 150, maybe 200 basis points from where we are and this is even before you buy Brocade, which comes in at gross margin in the 70s. So given all the levers that you just talked about and Brocade coming in, why should 64%, 65% which is where that should take you, why should that be the upper limit? Like how should be thinking about this if we're going farther? Like I don't see any reason why we shouldn't expect the gross margin going higher than that unless there something else mixed where there's something else that ought to be taking it down. Can you talk about that a little bit?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, Stacy, actually I think we're going to get into the gross margin of where we think we can go. And if I go back to the original Avago gross margins in the 30s, obviously we're always focused on continuing to improve on our gross margins. I think the
componenttext: Well, Stacy, actually I think we're going to get into the gross margin of where we think we can go. And if I go back to the original Avago gross margins in the 30s, obviously we're always focused on continuing to improve on our gross margins. I think the insightful part of the question is we are in our seasonally weak part of the year. And so when you do look at the general seasonality of the business and where things are you're going to have to take a whole fiscal year approach to looking at where operating margins will land and could land and apply that to thinking about the model. That's the only guidance I'd give you.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Vivek Arya with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Vivek Arya with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: My first one, Hock, your wired business has essentially been in this $2 billion to $2.1 billion range for the past year on a quarterly basis. Can you give us some puts and takes on what's done well? What's been different than expectations? Because my data
componenttext: My first one, Hock, your wired business has essentially been in this $2 billion to $2.1 billion range for the past year on a quarterly basis. Can you give us some puts and takes on what's done well? What's been different than expectations? Because my data is that the switching parts has probably done fairly well with all the cloud opportunities. But your broadband access and set-top boxes perhaps not done so well. But then on the prepared remarks, you mentioned that you are starting to see a little bit of pick up on the broadband access side. So just if you could give us a look back on what was different than expectations. And then as you look forward to this year, could we see contribution from both the parts of wired, both the cable side as well as the switching side?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: That's a very interesting -- good question actually, very insightful. Let me try to explain at on our wired business. You're right, it's a big segment. And yes, in simple term, broadly, there are 2 groups of product here and end markets here. There's swit
componenttext: That's a very interesting -- good question actually, very insightful. Let me try to explain at on our wired business. You're right, it's a big segment. And yes, in simple term, broadly, there are 2 groups of product here and end markets here. There's switching and routing, you correctly put out. And that comes from various fronts, from standard switching and routing as well as ASICs, which is also part in there as would be building block products as well as fiber optics components. That business is very enterprise driven, correctly, and it's actually done very well even on the year-on-year -- especially on a year-on-year basis, thus, it's growing. As we move from 10 gigabit a few years ago -- a couple of years ago to increasingly 25 and 100 coming up very fast and then transition happens very fast. Obviously, it's driving and you also see products like Trident going to Tomahawk especially in the very high end and Jericho. All these are related to data center switching. And that's very, very -- that's driving growth on a -- and my only presumption, on a very, very stable basis but driving growth very nicely, close to high single digits, even double digits. Then the other part of the segment, which is pretty big too, is our broadband. And here there's set-top box and the CP side and XO gateways, the DSL port on the infrastructure side. And here, the business is stable. It's very stable, has been stable for the last couple of years -- few years and continues to be very stable and it's also very seasonal. And you will see that the later part of the second half of the year is typically when it dries up. And in the first half of the year is when it shows a seasonal decline, hence in my opening remarks, I was mentioning that Q1 -- fiscal Q1 most probably -- is probably seasonal low point and is gradually -- picks up seasonally later part of Q2, but certainly Q3, and that starts rolling over again. But if you look at it year-on-year relatively very, very stable. So you have a confluence of 2 segments mixed together in our wired business, which is what you are seeing. It dilutes basically the strength, the growth of switching and routing. But nonetheless, both are very, very franchised product, very franchised business and drive stability in this company.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: And as my follow-up question, it's a somewhat longer-term question. You're obviously doing quite well in the wireless business and that can continue for some time. The cloud business is also doing quite well. But when I talked with a lot of your peers and
componenttext: And as my follow-up question, it's a somewhat longer-term question. You're obviously doing quite well in the wireless business and that can continue for some time. The cloud business is also doing quite well. But when I talked with a lot of your peers and asked them about the growth in semis over the next 3 to 5 years, they talk about connected cars or Internet of Things or machine learning or 5G. Do you think field Broadcom is investing adequately to pursue those markets? Is it a part of a company that is looking at those longer-term areas or do you think M&A is the better way to address some of those things as they become real over time?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Great question because [ph] using the opportunity to expound a little propaganda here again that we've always articulated. The franchise products we are in -- we are the technology, we are also the market leader in those areas, in those niches. Some of th
componenttext: Great question because [ph] using the opportunity to expound a little propaganda here again that we've always articulated. The franchise products we are in -- we are the technology, we are also the market leader in those areas, in those niches. Some of them are very large niche but we are the technology leader. And again we don't get there by not investing. We invested, as my remarks said and I said it many times, very heavily in those areas where -- we develop products that generally, in those franchise areas, before anybody else do it out there. And that's why we can sustain it, that's why our margins are the way it is because we provide products that are -- allow our customers to differentiate and innovate themselves. So we invest very heavily. And you look at our total R&D, we invest in total $2.7 billion a year as a company in R&D. We have the best engineers out there. We have the best product in this area. So that's really we where we continue to sustain leadership in our access franchise products. In some of those flights of fantasy somewhat that you have earlier, I'm not -- I'm not saying it won't happen. I'll be direct. Let somebody else take the -- easily and I will buy the company if they're successful. Thank you.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Toshiya Hari with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Toshiya Hari with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: I had one short-term question and then another longer-term question. Hock, on the short-term question, with regards to wireless, you talked about trends that you're Korean customer offsetting the seasonal trends of your North American customer. And theref
componenttext: I had one short-term question and then another longer-term question. Hock, on the short-term question, with regards to wireless, you talked about trends that you're Korean customer offsetting the seasonal trends of your North American customer. And therefore, you're guiding Q2 to be down only high single digits relative to history being down about 15, as I recall. Is the upside versus historical seasonality, is that all coming from dynamics at your Korean customer or dynamics in terms of units or content that you're North American customer trending better than history as well?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: You're really trying to pass the day, aren't you? It's really a combination, really. It is. And you obviously know all that. It's also timing of some of the bars shipments and processes by our 2 largest customers. So that become -- so there's a bunch -- a
componenttext: You're really trying to pass the day, aren't you? It's really a combination, really. It is. And you obviously know all that. It's also timing of some of the bars shipments and processes by our 2 largest customers. So that become -- so there's a bunch -- a few factors involved in that. One of which is timing, different quarter, differences in timing. That's a fact you're right. Korean customer is coming in with a vengeance to try to recover share. Oh, and broadly, we're also talking about content increases as each new generation comes in. And it's not even Korean customer, it's also the major North American customer. And it's a mix of all these sectors. Have I said -- broken it down in details? No. We don't try to analyze that to that degree. But those multiple sectors mixed pooled together to basically indicate that the seasonality -- the downward seasonality that we saw a year ago is perhaps less pronounced this year.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. That's helpful. And then as my follow-up, another question on wireless, specifically around China. Obviously, you're tied to the North American customer and the Korean customer in a big way today but when you think about your wireless busines
componenttext: Okay, great. That's helpful. And then as my follow-up, another question on wireless, specifically around China. Obviously, you're tied to the North American customer and the Korean customer in a big way today but when you think about your wireless business and your RF business specifically on CF3, your view, how do you think about the opportunity in China today?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, there are opportunities for us in China. And -- but the focus of our success and our product success in wireless, especially content increases year-on-year, is -- as you know, we push the cutting edge on technology, be it wireless WiFi connectivity
componenttext: Well, there are opportunities for us in China. And -- but the focus of our success and our product success in wireless, especially content increases year-on-year, is -- as you know, we push the cutting edge on technology, be it wireless WiFi connectivity or RF cellular. We push the envelope. And that tends to go very much or actually to the flagship-class phones. That's top of the pyramid, where it's -- we're a big part of it has been the major North American customer and the Korean customer, plus a few other guys spread around. That's where our strength is. That's where the demand value we see in our products coming out. As China evolves over time, having said that the opportunity increase, they'll move from feature phones to low-end smartphones to now some premium phones. And we begin to get a traction on you've in those premium phones to the extent that those brands which are under usage. And that's why they need the technological engineering edge that we provide our products. Until then, they needs less of it, except with exceptions like carrier aggregation where we obviously are the leader in providing solutions for a carrier aggregation on a discrete bases. But on an integrated basis into smartphones, it's really the flagship phones and now increasingly premium phones making its way into the flagship phones that we see the demand. And that transition is happening in China, albeit on a very gradual basis but we're very patient people, we'll wait for it.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: And our last question comes from the line of John Pitzer from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And our last question comes from the line of John Pitzer from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Hock, my first question is kind of a follow-up on the enterprise storage side. You rightfully pointed out that today, the SSD controller business is the smallest part of that business. I'm kind of curious as we look out over time, do you see that market d
componenttext: Hock, my first question is kind of a follow-up on the enterprise storage side. You rightfully pointed out that today, the SSD controller business is the smallest part of that business. I'm kind of curious as we look out over time, do you see that market developing similar and potentially getting the size of the HDD controller market? Or is there something inherent about the growing complexity of the raw demand itself, which means that there will always be kind of a large portion of the controller market, which is in-sourced to guys building the demand actually building their own controller? Do you think it eventually you'll end up in a situation where it's all outsourced?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: That's a very insightful question. And we see the SSD controllers for enterprise to be a lot -- a lot of it will be outsourced? Why? Because there are certain IP inherent in those enterprise flash controllers that are very tricky to do. Not dissimilar fro
componenttext: That's a very insightful question. And we see the SSD controllers for enterprise to be a lot -- a lot of it will be outsourced? Why? Because there are certain IP inherent in those enterprise flash controllers that are very tricky to do. Not dissimilar from rechannel of hard disk drives so that will happen. Client -- because the nature of client is not so complex -- I know the IP required is not so extreme. We perceive that is probably less opportunity for us, no one ever knows. But certainly on enterprise, which is why we're very focused on, we see a lot of need for intellectual property blocks features that few people can do. And we are one of those few people who can do it very well.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then, Hock, as my follow-up, I think a lot of us and investment community understands sort of the wireless both on the RF and the connectivity side, the content ASP story. I wondered if you could talk a little bit about that same dynam
componenttext: That's helpful. And then, Hock, as my follow-up, I think a lot of us and investment community understands sort of the wireless both on the RF and the connectivity side, the content ASP story. I wondered if you could talk a little bit about that same dynamic in your wired business and may be differentiate between switching and routing versus set-top box and broadband access. How do we think about sort of the ASP trends in those 2 segments over time? Or just your content going into the CapEx dollars being spent in the wired market.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, if you talk about switching and routing, it's really just more than chips, main building blocks of chips. It's really as much an architectural play. Especially in the high-end top of the rank in this -- and this buying side of the data centers. And
componenttext: Well, if you talk about switching and routing, it's really just more than chips, main building blocks of chips. It's really as much an architectural play. Especially in the high-end top of the rank in this -- and this buying side of the data centers. And here is where our model is going beyond just selling pieces of silicon. We sell a lot of firmware and software that goes hand-in-hand to enable those chips to work with multiple OEM customers at the end of the day. So that's a very interesting model for us. And what is overriding all this is obviously the need for more -- larger and larger, more and more throughput. And especially in data centers and especially in top of the rank and all the way to the spine. So we have a big advantages in this area is simply because of the strength of the intellectual property we have in -- in making very complex engineering, very complex SoCs but also interface  very high-speed interfaces of SerDes, as we call it. So all that plays to our ad vintage being able to do it. And we continue to do that. And we continue to -- as it goes from 10 gigabit to 25 to 50 to 100 and maybe even -- and going on in the future to 200 gigabit to 400 gigabit. We believe we are investing here heavily to ensure that we can develop those kind of products and develop it first and better than anybody else. So -- and with that the expansion of features, we benefit from content increases simply because you're providing a person more throughput. And it's not a one-on-one scaling. It's more and more -- it's a lot of value for our customers to be able to go from 25 gigabit or 10 gigabit to 100 in the next year or 2 and when we provide a lot of value on that. And by the way, in broadband, it's not dissimilar. In fact -- maybe it's not the evolving as rapidly, simply because it's a much more stable market. Once you hear about now 4K TVs, our video delivery, it's moving on to H -- high definition HD and then eventually moving even to 8K. It will all be interesting to see how 8K is going to be accepted since the human eye may not even notice the difference but people want that. And they want that. We're able to provide that. But it might take a bit longer, that's why I said broadband to us is a much -- we look at it as a much more stable, gradually evolving market even as OTT -- the hype behind OTT and all that comes to play which we participate in. But in data centers, it's serious stuff. More and more data are being basically pushed to pipes, thought, processed as social media keeps expanding. And that's why we are seeing this past quarter, in current quarter, extraordinarily strength in the demand for switching and routing.
