componenttext: Okay. I'll try another one on the networking snide. Can you talk about just the trajectory in the merchant silicon business, and any new kind of customer adoptions are ramps to think about there.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, we feel very good about merchant silicon in switching and now routing, as we call it, which is the DNX series on the Jericho, Jericho plus and all that. And we have launched of that. And they're are used not just as routers, they're used as aggregat
componenttext: Well, we feel very good about merchant silicon in switching and now routing, as we call it, which is the DNX series on the Jericho, Jericho plus and all that. And we have launched of that. And they're are used not just as routers, they're used as aggregation switching in the spine. And so it's a very good aggregation. So we pretty much cover in our merchant silicon even at the high-performance, high-capacity top of direct switching. We pretty much cover a full range of requirements. And so that's going along very well. In fact, very, very -- and the penetration, especially in the cloud guys is very, very good. Adoption among the hyperscale cloud guys is extremely strong, extremely well used. And while all this is going on, some penetration in enterprise is happening. But here in enterprise, traditional enterprise, our ASIC switch and routers continue to run very, very well through our OEM partners.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Hock, I just had a couple of questions on your wireless segment. One of the larger customers in there guided recently and a little weaker than expected for June quarter and talked about some weakness on the service providers side. So rather than by produc
componenttext: Hock, I just had a couple of questions on your wireless segment. One of the larger customers in there guided recently and a little weaker than expected for June quarter and talked about some weakness on the service providers side. So rather than by product type, can you talk about customer types. Are you seeing any change in the customer behavior that's -- it's under the covers within the mid-single-digit growth that you're talking about?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: No, we don't. We see, in this third quarter, very good data center spending. And as we said a lot of this is -- I assume when you say service provider you mean the cloud guys. And the cloud guys are very much focused on using merchant silicon on switching
componenttext: No, we don't. We see, in this third quarter, very good data center spending. And as we said a lot of this is -- I assume when you say service provider you mean the cloud guys. And the cloud guys are very much focused on using merchant silicon on switching and routing connectivity solutions. So -- and we see very strong spend, which is part of the reason why we are raising our sequential growth in Q3 from Q2 in wired to be a mid -- to be up to mid-single digits. Of course, it's also helped by the seasonal uptrend we are seeing in broadband access and set-top box which is CPE. That's typically seasonality. But it's not entirely that. It's also a switching and routing in data centers.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: And if my follow-up still within that same segment on broadband segment that you just talked about. Talk a little bit about that DOCSIS 3.1 could mean for you. With that rolling out, is there a chance that anything can be a little better than seasonal in
componenttext: And if my follow-up still within that same segment on broadband segment that you just talked about. Talk a little bit about that DOCSIS 3.1 could mean for you. With that rolling out, is there a chance that anything can be a little better than seasonal in your broadband business as we go to the second half of the calendar year? Or are they are offsets that we need to appreciate?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: I never try to be too optimistic. At this time of the year we see always a typical seasonality and and, boy are we seeing it now. Now and bookings out Q3 and at the beginning part of Q4. Very strong bookings. So I'd like to consider that seasonality rathe
componenttext: I never try to be too optimistic. At this time of the year we see always a typical seasonality and and, boy are we seeing it now. Now and bookings out Q3 and at the beginning part of Q4. Very strong bookings. So I'd like to consider that seasonality rather than unusual seasonality. This is normal.

componenttext: I know, you do. Very impressive questions. componenttext: Yes. Amit, again at this point, we're not updating our financial model. We're not updating our financial targets. So we're very comfortable at 45%.

componenttext: Fair enough. And if I just follow-up. Yes, if I think your gross margin guide for the upcoming quarter may, you have a nice 6% uptick in sales but you're thinking about gross margin of being flat even though I think the headwinds from wireless not being up as much should be a benefit. And last year I think your gross margin's up like 40, 50 basis points in July. Why can't we see the same level of leverage even mix might be better this July versus last July?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, we kind of give you what we see. We hate to miss forecast, guys, as you probably know. So we probably give you something that we're pretty comfortable with. And we are very comfortable at the midpoint of 63% which you are right, we achieved it last
componenttext: Well, we kind of give you what we see. We hate to miss forecast, guys, as you probably know. So we probably give you something that we're pretty comfortable with. And we are very comfortable at the midpoint of 63% which you are right, we achieved it last quarter.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: And Amit, I think we're going to be able to sustain in around that number. I think you're right, there's some wireless mix down with slightly headwind. We've also worked through a lot of the Broadcom synergies and the benefits we received there. But I thi
componenttext: And Amit, I think we're going to be able to sustain in around that number. I think you're right, there's some wireless mix down with slightly headwind. We've also worked through a lot of the Broadcom synergies and the benefits we received there. But I think we plan to sustain that going forward.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Toshiya Hari with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Toshiya Hari with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: I had a question on the long-term revenue growth targets. Obviously, you guys are committed to the mid-single digit targets you put out a couple of years ago. But as you pointed out, you grew 18% in the April quarter. If we take the midpoint of your July
componenttext: I had a question on the long-term revenue growth targets. Obviously, you guys are committed to the mid-single digit targets you put out a couple of years ago. But as you pointed out, you grew 18% in the April quarter. If we take the midpoint of your July quarter guide, I think you guys have with the quarter growing about 17%. I realize the growth rate in enterprise, for example, is not necessarily sustainable. But what prevents you from raising the target to say high single digits on a long-term basis?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: On the long-term basis, no because don't forget the characteristics of our product lines, all 18 of them, even the 19th one eventually, the Brocade, they are very sustainable. That's the single most important criteria, sustainable franchises. I mean they
componenttext: On the long-term basis, no because don't forget the characteristics of our product lines, all 18 of them, even the 19th one eventually, the Brocade, they are very sustainable. That's the single most important criteria, sustainable franchises. I mean they deliver value added and they keep delivering it the generation after generation. They're not there to grow like weeds. They are not. But they grew like GDP pretty much, economic growth. We've then added that each generation had value added which entitles us to have a slight premium but not much. And hence, it's mid-single digits which is GDP but plus that slight premium. No more than that. And that is long term the sustainable amount basis because it's the nature of the product we invest in. But if it makes the nature of our business model. What you see now I think is a short-term event, which is driven the 18% -- 17%, 18% that you mentioned year-on-year in Q2 from last year. It's driven by 2 parts is my view on this whole matter. One is wireless. As the Q2 of the year ago, it's not because that Q2 of this year is strong as much as the Q2 a year ago in wireless was unusually weak for good reasons many of which I will not go into but you all know that. And this quarter, it's more of a normal Q2, perhaps somewhat buttressed by a strong launch of our big Korean customer. But kind of stronger than we expected, as I mentioned. So there's -- a big part of that double-digit growth is wireless growth driving it, and that's 30% of our total revenues approximately. So if it grows a lot, it has that impact. And the second part of it is on infrastructure. Our business in wired, industrial and enterprise storage, this year, [ 17 business ] is just strong. The site just rose. And I think that the other part that drove this double-digit growth. But you don't see that every year. In fact, I think this year it's fairly unusually strong for infrastructure. But from wireless infrastructure itself. So that combination is what creates this 18% growth. I would not, for a second, like you guys to think -- believe that this is something we will sustain for the next 5 years. What we feel comfortable we can sustain for the next 5 years is what we had said before and we'll continue to deliver, hopefully over the next 5, 10 years which is mid-single digit growth on average year after year.

componenttext: Okay. Got it. And then my follow-up, I just wanted to ask a follow-up question on M&A, and I realized public the eldest of this sensitive here. But Hock, you told us to not believe everything we read in the papers. Is it okay for us to walk away thinking that you're not make the bids for that specific asset or -- again I think [indiscernible] the gentleman who asked the question before...

componenttextpreview: Let me reiterate. Please do not believe everything you read and we do not comment on any rumors or pure speculation in the headline. But we continue to focus on our franchise stable business model. We have lots of free cash flow.
componenttext: Let me reiterate. Please do not believe everything you read and we do not comment on any rumors or pure speculation in the headline. But we continue to focus on our franchise stable business model. We have lots of free cash flow.

componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Harlan Sur with JPMorgan.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: On the topic of free cash flow, you guys generated 32% free cash flow margins. If I normalize for your target of 3% of CapEx, you guys actually did 35% free cash flow margins which is your target model. But I'm wondering despite the great cash generation,
componenttext: On the topic of free cash flow, you guys generated 32% free cash flow margins. If I normalize for your target of 3% of CapEx, you guys actually did 35% free cash flow margins which is your target model. But I'm wondering despite the great cash generation, do you guys still have some restructuring, acquisition-related cash charges which would imply that the normalized free cash flow, even now, is better than what you printed? And maybe you guys can quantify some of those cash restructuring charges?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: No, you're right. You're doing your math absolutely right. The company I mean, taking into account the elevated CapEx were mostly the campus investments we're making that you're aware of and some incremental restructuring charges and frankly some working
componenttext: No, you're right. You're doing your math absolutely right. The company I mean, taking into account the elevated CapEx were mostly the campus investments we're making that you're aware of and some incremental restructuring charges and frankly some working capital headwinds as the business continues to grow. --  you'll quickly get to 35%, in which is where we want to be. And obviously, we're going to continue putting those numbers going forward based on where we see revenues and the gross margins and operating expenses that we outlined for you, we think that's achievable.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Great. And then for my follow-up question within enterprise storage. You guys has got a leadership position in server RAID and SaaS controller solutions. And typically these products tend to track given server shipments. So given Intel's Skylake server CP
componenttext: Great. And then for my follow-up question within enterprise storage. You guys has got a leadership position in server RAID and SaaS controller solutions. And typically these products tend to track given server shipments. So given Intel's Skylake server CPU launch and you've got AMD's Epiq server CPU launch, both I think which are ramping now, is this contributing to the growth here in the July quarter and maybe to the second half of this calendar year?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Not in the quarter we just ended, Q2, nor necessarily much in the July quarter, Q3. But certainly, we expect -- which is the generation you are talking about for Intel launching Skylake, the -- generation in storage will start to ramp-up on, you're right,
componenttext: Not in the quarter we just ended, Q2, nor necessarily much in the July quarter, Q3. But certainly, we expect -- which is the generation you are talking about for Intel launching Skylake, the -- generation in storage will start to ramp-up on, you're right, back half of this calendar year, really back half of this calendar year.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: And our next question goes the line of John Pitzer with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question goes the line of John Pitzer with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Hock, I want to talk a little bit about the wired results just for the April quarter. There's a lot of different businesses inside of wired. But the 3% year-over-year growth rate I think is kind of the slowest growth rate that we've seen since the financi
componenttext: Hock, I want to talk a little bit about the wired results just for the April quarter. There's a lot of different businesses inside of wired. But the 3% year-over-year growth rate I think is kind of the slowest growth rate that we've seen since the financial crisis. And so I'm just curious if you could give us a little bit color us to what exactly happened in the April quarter where there was some strength and where there might have been some relative weakness. And then as you think about sort of the reacceleration into July, maybe some color within segments within wired would be helpful as well.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Wow, that's interesting -- very confusing question but let me try somewhat. And for the rest, I might have to take it off-line another time because there are a lot of moving parts. And you're correct, in our wired segment, which represents 50% of revenue,
componenttext: Wow, that's interesting -- very confusing question but let me try somewhat. And for the rest, I might have to take it off-line another time because there are a lot of moving parts. And you're correct, in our wired segment, which represents 50% of revenue, we throw in the kitchen sink. Not really. All related to wired. There's actually a couple of chunks on broadband, which is broadband access, carrier access as well as CPE set-top box. And in Q2, those were not that strong obviously. It starts ramping up seasonally Q3, Q4 -- Q3 to Q4. So that effect that is not that strong. And year-on-year, a year ago -- a year ago, if you recall that was the Summer Olympics so we're comparing against the Summer Olympics which will make it tough. And in Q3, Q4 there's Fall Summer Olympics of last years to the begin to look very good which is what accelerates this in the second half. In switching and routing, no, we continue to feel very, very good. Whether it's in ASIC or merchant silicon, offtake delivery shipments continue to hit all-time highs in those 2 segments. I hope that gives you enough -- and then first thing that matters with us is we have building block products like -- -- which are more unique to the designs that have been used as well as fiber optics, which has gone through very interesting generations and cycles that may mess up the number. But the 2 broadest area. Broadband compared to a year ago is hard to compare because of Summer Olympics. But switching and routing being it as it may continues to be a very, very strong franchise whether it's in the form of a ASIC or a form of a merchant silicon even though they're both selling into very different end-users.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then, Hock, maybe for my follow up, on the ASIC side, I sort of have a juggle question. You've always had a strong switching routing ASIC business. It's my understanding you're also doing ASICs for things like SSD controllers and perha
componenttext: That's helpful. And then, Hock, maybe for my follow up, on the ASIC side, I sort of have a juggle question. You've always had a strong switching routing ASIC business. It's my understanding you're also doing ASICs for things like SSD controllers and perhaps the things like imprints or deep learning. I'm just kind of curious, how do you think about the ASIC IP that Broadcom had? And would you consider that as franchise? And is it leverageable into areas beyond just switching and routing?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Oh, yes. You hit it right on. We do do deep learning ASICs, that means customized deep learning chips for specific customers. We do that. Because we have all the IP and hardware needed. Keep in mind, I believe deep learning is very much as much a software
componenttext: Oh, yes. You hit it right on. We do do deep learning ASICs, that means customized deep learning chips for specific customers. We do that. Because we have all the IP and hardware needed. Keep in mind, I believe deep learning is very much as much a software play much more than a hardware play. But we're happy to enable that for specific large customers in ASIC with customized hardware, which we do even right now. And retraining our influence but we do that. Then on SSD controllers, yes, you do a huge amount of SSD controllers relatively speaking for -- basically for enterprises only. Large enterprises. But they're all part in our enterprise storage business. They're not part in our wired business. And that business is doing very well as you probably can gather today.

componenttext: First, I wanted to ask about the cash flow. So again, I can see the margins are bumping up you can normalize those the 35%. What about the payout ratio? So the payout ratio is still running around 5%. We're not close to 50. What's stopping you from bringing closer to 50% earlier? What's the trajectory that we should be thinking about for you to get to that target payout ratio?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. Hey, Stacy. I think we had reiterated a couple quarters back when we put in place the updated financial policies that we're going to evaluate that once a year at the end of our fiscal year. So that will be in October-November time frame. We're going
componenttext: Yes. Hey, Stacy. I think we had reiterated a couple quarters back when we put in place the updated financial policies that we're going to evaluate that once a year at the end of our fiscal year. So that will be in October-November time frame. We're going to look back over our last fiscal year, look at that cash flow generation, look at the sustainability of the businesses that we're focused on and then make a assessment, obviously with the board's approval, around a recommendation. But what I want to reiterate is you're right, as we continue to perform, if we maintain what we should plan to do a 50% payout, then that's going to lead to obviously, an increase and potentially a substantial increase dividend come end of the year.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Got it. For my follow-up. I don't want to beat a dead horse but can you refresh us on your definition of a franchise? What are the characteristics of a business that meets that definition? And frankly, would it be possible for a NAND flash business to qua
componenttext: Got it. For my follow-up. I don't want to beat a dead horse but can you refresh us on your definition of a franchise? What are the characteristics of a business that meets that definition? And frankly, would it be possible for a NAND flash business to qualify as a franchise under your definition?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good try. Okay, let me give your definition a franchise, which is very open and I'm glad you asked -- gave me a chance to repeat the mantra. No, a franchise basically is a -- we do only components, semiconductor components and just components broadly is s
componenttext: Good try. Okay, let me give your definition a franchise, which is very open and I'm glad you asked -- gave me a chance to repeat the mantra. No, a franchise basically is a -- we do only components, semiconductor components and just components broadly is simply that it operates -- that product line operates in a niche. it doesn't have to be mass-market, most times it's a niche. It's a niche where the markets are -- have been established and will likely to continue to be established for the foreseeable future. So we must have established end markets that are sustainable, one. And in that niche, in that market, we are the market leader. And more than a market leader, especially because when we are -- the reason for us being the market leader, we are the technology leader. We have to have the IP, we have to have the technology and the capability to continue to lead in that particular market. And the third, there's nothing financial about it. The financial is a fallout, a corollary fall out from those key criteria. And each of our 18 product lines meet those criteria. It's -- you make your own call whether NAND meets that criteria.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: That deep learning product we're doing for multiple customers today are all customized solutions, hardware solutions on our side. They're not software-based solutions. We do -- we're -- it falls into our ASIC category. And we have all kinds of intellectua
componenttext: That deep learning product we're doing for multiple customers today are all customized solutions, hardware solutions on our side. They're not software-based solutions. We do -- we're -- it falls into our ASIC category. And we have all kinds of intellectual property, largely all hardware-based like SerDes, much more than SerDes, memories, you name it all kind of stuff that goes into training and inference on a deep learning chip. We have all that IP. But we're only doing hardware. We make no pretensions a try and make it the full solution. So it's an ASIC solution and it covers multiple customers and it probably covers multiple generations going forward. But it's really simply an ASIC solution.

componenttext: Hock, I just want to ask a clarifying question to the previous answer. Some of your peers are putting this market opportunity at close to $30 billion. I just want to hear your thoughts of how big the ASIC opportunity for deep learning in European -- is if you take may be a 3-year view on this?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: I have no clue to be honest. Seriously, no. It is -- our franchise here is the intellectual property capability we have of implementing silicon solutions that does deep learning. We could just as well have the IP implemented to do high-performance computi
componenttext: I have no clue to be honest. Seriously, no. It is -- our franchise here is the intellectual property capability we have of implementing silicon solutions that does deep learning. We could just as well have the IP implemented to do high-performance computing or as we do would now a lot of switching and routing. This we do in deep learning. And for us, deep learning is not seen necessarily as a franchise. It's our ASIC capability that is a franchise.

componenttext: Got it. And I know you on your competitors trash talk. But if you could maybe comment on in terms of your BAW performance, I think historically, the reason you had such a significant share was you had a significant performance advantage over your competitors. I'm just trying to understand if some of your peers are closing that gap or at least narrowing the gap? And as we look out to the next couple of years I just want to understand how much advantage you'll still have in BAW?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Remember my definition of a sustainable franchise? We don't stop investing. I mean, contrary to myths out there, we actually -- every time we fix a particular product line as our core product lines as one, the 18, we invest as much as we have to to mainta
componenttext: Remember my definition of a sustainable franchise? We don't stop investing. I mean, contrary to myths out there, we actually -- every time we fix a particular product line as our core product lines as one, the 18, we invest as much as we have to to maintain, if not lengthen our lead. No different here. We don't stay put at the generation of last year or 2 years ago or 3 years ago. We continue to invest the lead, to be right review, never closes. And that's the key part of our model. We will invest. And given that the market we're the market leader in that niche, we can't afford to out invest anyone out there. We have been in R&D for this entire company as you noticed that in totality, some of it pops up and cost of sales or product engineering as we bring it to production. The rest of it in R&D. We've spent on product development in this company every year $3 billion. And that's not counting CapEx. $3 billion. And we are very, very conscious of the fact that we have to maintain, it's not even increase that level of spending where we need to live in specific areas to ensure that we are the leader both in technology, which leads to market leader. So not that easy to narrow the lead in terms of coming to compete with us.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Hock, if I could -- I wanted to follow-up on your earlier comments on the storage -- your storage business and your guidance for stable demand beginning in this -- your fiscal third quarter. I was wondering if we're looking back earlier this year, where t
componenttext: Hock, if I could -- I wanted to follow-up on your earlier comments on the storage -- your storage business and your guidance for stable demand beginning in this -- your fiscal third quarter. I was wondering if we're looking back earlier this year, where the storage business has seen better demand because of some of the shortages in NAND flash and for SSDs. I was wondering if your customers are providing you much commentary on whether the current hard drive demand is in line with broader demand? Or if there's still some element of NAND that these shortages that are helping the hard drive demand?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: This is a very hard market to predict at this point, because there are a lot of multiple dynamics going on in terms of -- it's not just about flash demand being -- reaching very high levels, which is driving everything else. Probably is but that was proba
componenttext: This is a very hard market to predict at this point, because there are a lot of multiple dynamics going on in terms of -- it's not just about flash demand being -- reaching very high levels, which is driving everything else. Probably is but that was probably late '16, early '17. Today, I guess, all of this increase prices in memory whether DRAM, Flash, non-hard drive as much as DRAM and Flash, is leading to careful spending by enterprises and operators and cloud guys and data center guys. They all have been very careful. So suddenly, you have demand that is there, that is needed but people are not spending. And you will have these stops and starts going on. So it's all very confusing is what I'm trying to get on. And I'm not sure we have as much embedded we have an embedded visibility that even our customers or our customers have better visibility than us for that matter. It's just very confusing. And all we can see is that demand has flattened out for our products be they SSDs or be they SSD flash controllers I should clarify or be they components -- channels and preempts for hard disk drive. All we see is that a quarter ago, we are saying got to be careful about Q3. While Q2 has come and gone. Q2 was good. Q3 continues to look good. But then I'm going to -- say Q4 may cave? Who knows. We're still booked in Q4 and but it may not be a strong. A big part of that uncertainty lies in the fact that they're more than just simply a shortage of flash or DRAMs that's creating this uncertainty. I think it's much more than that. It's also the change in spending patterns even in the short term of data center guys cloud guys and enterprises because of higher memory prices.

componenttext: No. They are -- they are I guess, the best way to describe is broadband carrier [indiscernible] are increasingly even set-top box vision would set-top box both CPE that is as well as central office are starting to sprout WiFi as another means. You have GPON, EPON, you have DSL, VDSL. Now WiFi into the picture. So it's all good. And we are very, very well positioned in all of this, including next generation. So it is giving us more content to be put it this way at every access point which may help the growth. But it's still not as big by the way, as the [ phone ] by comparison the volume. But it's a decent amount of volume and gives us a very sustainable franchise in this area as well.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Broadcom Limited's Second Quarter Fiscal Year 2017 Financial Results Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Ashish Saran, Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, si
componenttext:
Welcome to Broadcom Limited's Second Quarter Fiscal Year 2017 Financial Results Conference Call. 
At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Ashish Saran, Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator, and good afternoon, everyone. Joining me today are Hock Tan, President and CEO; and Tom Krause, Chief Financial Officer of Broadcom Limited. After market close today, Broadcom distributed a press release and financial tables describ
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and good afternoon, everyone. Joining me today are Hock Tan, President and CEO; and Tom Krause, Chief Financial Officer of Broadcom Limited. 
After market close today, Broadcom distributed a press release and financial tables describing our financial performance for the second quarter of fiscal year 2017. If you did not receive a copy, you may obtain the information from the Investors section of Broadcom's website at www.broadcom.com.
This conference call is being webcast live, and a recording will be made available via telephone playback for 1 week. It will also be archived in the Investors section of our website at broadcom.com. 
During the prepared comments section of this call, Hock and Tom will be providing details of our second quarter of fiscal year 2017 results, background to our third quarter fiscal year 2017 outlook and some commentary regarding the business environment. We will take questions after the end of our prepared comments.
In addition to U.S. GAAP reporting, Broadcom reports certain financial measures on a non-GAAP basis. A reconciliation between GAAP and non-GAAP measures is included in the tables attached to today's press release. Comments made during today's call will primarily refer to our non-GAAP financial results. Please refer to our press release today and our recent filings with the SEC for information on the specific risk factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statements made on this call.
At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Hock Tan. Hock?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ashish. Good afternoon, everyone. I'm actually quite pleased with our performance for the second fiscal quarter with solid contributions from a broad number of our franchises. We delivered strong financial results with revenue, gross margin a
componenttext:
Thank you, Ashish. Good afternoon, everyone. 
I'm actually quite pleased with our performance for the second fiscal quarter with solid contributions from a broad number of our franchises. We delivered strong financial results with revenue, gross margin and earnings per share, all above the top line -- top end of our guidance.
Second quarter revenue of $4.2 billion grew 1% sequentially and 18% year-on-year. The seasonal sequential decline in our wireless segment was less than expected and more than offset by contributions from all other segments. All segments, even wireless, delivered year-on-year revenue growth. On the income front, earnings per share were $3.69, growing by 2% sequentially and 46% year-on-year.
Let me now turn to the discussion of our results by segment. Starting with wired, our largest segment. In the second quarter, wired revenue was very stable at $2.1 billion, growing 1% sequentially and 3% year-on-year. The wired segment represented 50% of our total revenue. Wired continue to remain a very consistent end market and perform in line with expectations. 
As you may recall in the preceding quarter, wired revenue included approximately $60 million of revenue related to the assignment of certain manufacturer's right to a customer. This did not repeat in the second quarter. However, we were able to more than make up for this amount with growth from enterprise networking and the start of a seasonal increase in demand for our broadband access and set-top box products. 
Turning to the third fiscal quarter. Though we expect seasonal strength in broadband and sustained cloud data center spend and consistent with this outlook, we expect wired revenue growth to accelerate into mid-single digits, sequentially. 
Moving on to wireless. Second quarter wireless revenue was $1.15 billion, declining by 2% sequentially but growing 45% year-on-year. Wireless -- the wireless segment represented 28% of our total revenue. The low single-digit sequential decline in revenue was better than expected due to stronger-than-anticipated end-market demand. The sequential decline was driven by the bottom of the annual product cycle transition at our major North American customer, offset by the ramp of the next-generation phone at our large Korean smartphone customer. Generation-to-generation, we also benefited from significant increase in Broadcom's cellular and WiFi connectivity content.
Moving on now to the third quarter. We expect to see the beginning of the second half seasonal growth in our wireless segment revenue. We expect this growth to be driven by the start of a ramp from a north -- large North American smartphone customer as they transition to their next-generation platform. On top of this, we are also expecting a substantial increase in our total dollar content from the 8 Broadcom products we will be supplying into this new platform. The initial ramp of this next-generation platform, however, appears slower this year compared to prior years but we believe this will likely accelerate in our fourth quarter. 
Our third fiscal quarter outlook reflects this expectation. And notwithstanding the 40% content growth, we project sequential growth in our wireless revenue to only approach double digits on a percentage basis. This outlook also reflects an expected decline in shipments to our large Korean smartphone customer. 
Let me now turn to enterprise storage. In the second quarter, enterprise storage revenue was $712 million, growing 1% sequentially and 36% year-on-year. Storage segment represented 17% of our total revenue. Surprisingly, this segment continued to hold up and perform as expected. Hard disk drive and custom SSD shipments grew while SaaS and RAID sustained, offset by a seasonal decline in Fibre Channel shipments. 
During our previous earnings call, we expressed a cautionary tone around enterprise storage for the third quarter. However, we continue to see stability and, most of all, sustained bookings. We expect storage revenue to grow in the low single digits sequentially into the third quarter.
And finally, our last segment, industrial. In the second quarter, the industrial segment revenue was $223 million, growing by 24% sequentially, much better than expected primarily due to higher IP, intellectual property, that is, licensing revenue from a large deal we closed in the quarter. Industrial revenue grew 23% year-on-year and represented 5% of our total revenue. Resales of our industrial products continue to trend up very firmly in the second quarter and we expect this to continue to be strong into the next quarter. As we look to the third quarter, we expect industrial revenue to grow in the mid-single digits, sequentially.
So in summary, demand in the second quarter, which is historically our weakest seasonal quarter, was stronger than expected. For the third fiscal quarter, end markets in wired, enterprise, storage and industrial continue to be strong, while wireless turns around and starts a slower-than-usual seasonal second half ramp. Although we do expect it to accelerate dramatically in the fourth quarter. This leads to a projection of consolidated revenue growth of around 6% sequentially for the third quarter. 
With that, let me turn the call over to Tom for a more detailed review of our second quarter financials and third quarter outlook.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Hock, and good afternoon, everyone. My comments today will focus primarily on our non-GAAP results from continuing operations, unless otherwise specifically noted. The reconciliation of our GAAP to non-GAAP data is included with the earnings re
componenttext:
Thank you, Hock, and good afternoon, everyone. My comments today will focus primarily on our non-GAAP results from continuing operations, unless otherwise specifically noted. The reconciliation of our GAAP to non-GAAP data is included with the earnings release issued today and is also available on our website at broadcom.com.
[Audio Gap] for the second quarter, starting with revenue of $4.2 billion which grew by 1% sequentially. Year-on-year growth for the second quarter revenue was 18%, which I would note is -- continues to be well ahead of our long-term growth rate targets of mid-single digits. Foxconn was the only greater-than-10% direct customer in the second fiscal quarter.
Our second quarter gross margins from continuing operations was 63.1%, 70 basis points higher than our prior quarter and 110 basis points above the midpoint of guidance. The improvement in gross margin's primarily due to lower revenue and better-than-expected IP licensing revenue within our industrial and other segment. I would note we do expect to be able to sustain these gross margins going forward.
Turning to operating expenses. R&D expenses were $677 million, and SG&A expenses were $122 million totaling $799 million or 19% of net revenue for the second quarter. This is slightly higher than guidance as we accrued for a larger projected annual bonus compensation expense driven by better-than-expected operating income. As I mentioned last quarter, we are comfortable at this relative level of operating expense given our current portfolio of businesses.
Operating income from continuing operations for the quarter was $1.85 billion and represented 44.1% of net revenue. We now have line of sight to achieving our long-term operating margin target of 45%. 
Provision for taxes came in at $78 million, slightly above our guidance. This is primarily due to higher-than-expected net income. 
Second quarter interest expense was $112 million; and other income, net, was $3 million. 
Second quarter net income was $1.67 billion, and earnings per diluted share was $3.69. Our share-based compensation expense in the second quarter was $216 million.
Moving on to the balance sheet. Our days sales outstanding were 45 days, an increase of 2 days from the prior quarter due to a reduction in linearity of revenue in the quarter. Our inventory ended at $1.31 billion, a decrease of $25 million from the beginning of the quarter. 
We generated $1.58 billion in operational cash flow, which does include the impact of an increase in working capital. 
Expenditures on classic Broadcom restructuring and integration activities continues to decline, as expected, as we expended approximately by $15 million -- $50 million in cash on these activities in the second quarter.
Free cash flow in the second quarter was $1.33 billion or 32% of net revenue. I would note, we are making very good progress towards our long-term target of 35%. 
Capital expenditure in the second quarter was $256 million or 6.1% of net revenue. As a reminder, we do expect our long-term CapEx to decline to about 3% of net revenue.
A total of $437 million in cash was spent on company dividend partnership distribution payments in the second quarter. 
We ended the second quarter with cash and short-term investments balance of $4.45 billion. Our cash balance is running at elevated levels, which we expect will continue through the third quarter in anticipation of closing the pending acquisition of Brocade.
Now let me turn to our non-GAAP guidance for the third quarter of fiscal year 2017. This guidance reflects our current assessment of business conditions, and we do not intend to update this guidance. This guidance is for results from continuing operations only.
Net revenue is expected to be $4.45 billion, plus or minus $75 million. Gross margins is expected to be 63%, plus or minus 1 percentage point. Operating expenses are estimated to be approximately $787 million. Our tax provision is forecasted to be approximately $86 million. Net interest expense and other is expected to be approximately $100 million. Note this reflects anticipated interest expense on our long-term debt of $112 million offset largely by other income, including interest earned on our cash balance. The diluted share count forecast is for 456 million shares. Share-based compensation expense will be approximately $255 million. Capital expenditures will be approximately $240 million.
As you will have seen, our board has declared a dividend of $1.02 per share to be paid later in this fiscal -- third fiscal quarter. 
We are looking forward to completing the acquisition of Brocade, which is proceeding as planned. And subject to the satisfaction of the remaining closing conditions, we presently expect to close this transaction on or about July 31, 2017.
That concludes my prepared remarks. Operator, please open up the call for questions.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: It's timing. I think it's timing. Last year, the similar ramp was earlier in Q -- it was stronger in Q3 probably because it was earlier. And here, the initial volume in our fiscal Q3 was smaller made up with content on our side. But definitely, Q4 is fore
componenttext: It's timing. I think it's timing. Last year, the similar ramp was earlier in Q -- it was stronger in Q3 probably because it was earlier. And here, the initial volume in our fiscal Q3 was smaller made up with content on our side. But definitely, Q4 is forecast to be larger.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: And then you mention this of the storage side. You had some conservatism on the second half and you're seeing growth. Maybe you can just talk about what you're seeing on the storage side that is growing, and then what are you seeing -- I think your hard d
componenttext: And then you mention this of the storage side. You had some conservatism on the second half and you're seeing growth. Maybe you can just talk about what you're seeing on the storage side that is growing, and then what are you seeing -- I think your hard drives, where you're most concerned, what's making you feel better about that market?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, it's growing, as we mentioned, pretty much single digits -- low single digits. I would say it's at a high, elevated level and kind of staying there for now in Q3. Q4 of course, as we expressed in a cautionary manner, is a whole new game. And visibil
componenttext: Well, it's growing, as we mentioned, pretty much single digits -- low single digits. I would say it's at a high, elevated level and kind of staying there for now in Q3. Q4 of course, as we expressed in a cautionary manner, is a whole new game. And visibility is -- we obviously are not booking everything in Q4 yet, but we've pretty much booked Q3.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of the Vivek Arya with Bank of America.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of the Vivek Arya with Bank of America.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: For my first question, Hock, can you please address these recent media reports about the potentially large bid for Toshiba's assets? I realize that details are not public, but there is a very large amount of money involved and I think investors are keen t
componenttext: For my first question, Hock, can you please address these recent media reports about the potentially large bid for Toshiba's assets? I realize that details are not public, but there is a very large amount of money involved and I think investors are keen to know how you are thinking about it conceptually and whether you are still committed to being disciplined around maintaining your free cash flow returns and not taking big technology risks when you consider M&A.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: We are very committed to our business model of only having franchises, very much so. And as I mentioned, all 18 of product lines are product franchises in connectivity solutions. We are also very committed to not only those franchises but generating lots
componenttext: We are very committed to our business model of only having franchises, very much so. And as I mentioned, all 18 of product lines are product franchises in connectivity solutions. We are also very committed to not only those franchises but generating lots and lots of free cash flow, which we -- half of which we will return to shareholders. All that part of the model, no change. Bottom line, don't believe everything you read out there, please.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: I see. And then secondly, on the wireless business, I think you gave some good color for Q3. Just one question on Q4 and then maybe longer term. Q4, when I look at the last 5 years, the median sort of sequential growth has been close to 30%. So is that th
componenttext: I see. And then secondly, on the wireless business, I think you gave some good color for Q3. Just one question on Q4 and then maybe longer term. Q4, when I look at the last 5 years, the median sort of sequential growth has been close to 30%. So is that the kind of level that you're thinking about this year or maybe even better, given the delayed shipments of those phones and the higher content you suggested? And then longer term on that same wireless theme, I think one of your competitors, Qorvo, recently outlined some plans to perhaps take some share at your large customer with a high-band pad. And I wanted to see how secure you think your competitive position is on next year's phone models.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Boy, that's a lot of questions and content. Let's start with the serious one. We don't forecast beyond one quarter. Bad practice, frankly, because we could be very sadly wrong. But obviously, what we are also saying is from the limited visibility we see,
componenttext: Boy, that's a lot of questions and content. Let's start with the serious one. We don't forecast beyond one quarter. Bad practice, frankly, because we could be very sadly wrong. But obviously, what we are also saying is from the limited visibility we see, we see the ramp beginning in our fiscal Q3, which, as you know, is an off-calendar ramp by 1 month, July. So we capture a part of that ramp, I believe -- we believe, a small part. And we expect to capture the substantial part of that ramp in Q4. But keep in mind comes always when you compare year-on-year, we have different content levels from a year ago, substantially, as I pointed out. So that might kind of confuse the numbers somewhat. But enough -- suffice to say, Q3, as we outlined since the beginning of the ramp, may not be the same level of ramp if you compare to a year ago for a couple of reasons I mentioned. But we also see Q4 to even ramp up even more substantially, obviously, because if Q3 is slower, it's more than likely Q4 in any product ramp will just show a stronger quarter compared to Q3. So that's it. But after -- the specifics, really, we're -- I'm not really at liberty to disclose it because we just don't go look that far out. As far as the fresh stuff you hear out there, seriously, we don't prefer to -- I prefer not to comment on that.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Craig Hettenbach with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Craig Hettenbach with Morgan Stanley.
