headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. I'll try another one. On the networking side, can you talk about just the trajectory in the merchant silicon business and any new kind of customer adoptions or ramps to think about there?
componenttext: Okay. I'll try another one. On the networking side, can you talk about just the trajectory in the merchant silicon business and any new kind of customer adoptions or ramps to think about there?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, we feel very good about our merchant silicon in switching, and now, routing, as we call it, which is the DNX series on the Jericho, Jericho plus and all that. And we have launched that. And they are used not just as routers, they're used as aggregat
componenttext: Well, we feel very good about our merchant silicon in switching, and now, routing, as we call it, which is the DNX series on the Jericho, Jericho plus and all that. And we have launched that. And they are used not just as routers, they're used as aggregation switching in the spine. And so it's a very good aggregation. So we pretty much cover in our merchant silicon, even at the high-performance, high-capacity, top of direct switching, we pretty much cover a full range of requirements, and so that's going along very well. In fact, very, very -- and the penetration, especially in the cloud guys, is very, very good. Adoption among the hyperscale cloud guys is extremely strong, extremely well used. And while all this is going on, some penetration in enterprise is happening, but here in enterprise, traditional enterprise, our ASIC switch and routers continue to run very, very well through our OEM partners.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Ross Seymore with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Ross Seymore with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Hock, I just had a couple of questions on your wired segment. One of the larger customers in there guided recently and -- a little weaker than expected for their June quarter and talked about some weakness on the service provider side. So rather than by p
componenttext: Hock, I just had a couple of questions on your wired segment. One of the larger customers in there guided recently and -- a little weaker than expected for their June quarter and talked about some weakness on the service provider side. So rather than by product type, can you talk about customer types? Are you seeing any change in the customer behavior that is under the covers within that mid-single-digit growth that you're talking about?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: No, we don't. We see, in this third quarter, very good data center spending. And as I said, a lot of this is -- I assume when you say service provider, you mean the cloud guys. And the cloud guys are very much focused on using merchant silicon on switchin
componenttext: No, we don't. We see, in this third quarter, very good data center spending. And as I said, a lot of this is -- I assume when you say service provider, you mean the cloud guys. And the cloud guys are very much focused on using merchant silicon on switching and routing connectivity solutions, so -- and we see very strong spend, which is part of the reason why we are raising our sequential growth in Q3 from Q2 in wired to be mid- -- to up to mid-single digits. Of course, it's also helped by the seasonal uptrend we are seeing in broadband access and set-top box, which is CPE. That's typically seasonality, but it's not entirely that. It's also switching and routing in data centers.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: And as my follow-up, still within that same segment, on the broadband segment that you just talked about, talk a little bit about what DOCSIS 3.1 could mean for you. With that rolling out, is there a chance that things can be a little better than seasonal
componenttext: And as my follow-up, still within that same segment, on the broadband segment that you just talked about, talk a little bit about what DOCSIS 3.1 could mean for you. With that rolling out, is there a chance that things can be a little better than seasonal in your broadband business as we go into the second half of the calendar year? Or are there offsets that we need to appreciate?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: I never try to be too optimistic. At this time of the year, we see always the typical seasonality, and boy, are we seeing it now. Now -- and bookings out Q3 and at the beginning part of Q4, very strong bookings. But I'd like to consider that seasonality r
componenttext: I never try to be too optimistic. At this time of the year, we see always the typical seasonality, and boy, are we seeing it now. Now -- and bookings out Q3 and at the beginning part of Q4, very strong bookings. But I'd like to consider that seasonality rather than unusual seasonality. This is normal.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Amit Daryanani with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Amit Daryanani with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions for me as well. I guess, to start off with, as you look at your operating margin target, around 45% -- you guys are 44.1% right now, and I think Brocade alone, once it closes, gets you north of that. So how should we think about marg
componenttext: A couple of questions for me as well. I guess, to start off with, as you look at your operating margin target, around 45% -- you guys are 44.1% right now, and I think Brocade alone, once it closes, gets you north of that. So how should we think about margins as we go forward? Is the desire to keep taking margins higher? Or do you think there's price elasticity in this market, where you'd perhaps keep margins the way they are and drive revenue growth faster?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Boy, you ask very complicated, strategic questions. All -- we...
componenttext: Boy, you ask very complicated, strategic questions. All -- we...

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Which is a good thing.
componenttext: Which is a good thing.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: I know, you do. Very impressive questions, but you won't get as impressive an answer, though, I have to say that because all we're doing is we sell based on the value add that we provide our very key customers. That's actually what it is. And we believe w
componenttext: I know, you do. Very impressive questions, but you won't get as impressive an answer, though, I have to say that because all we're doing is we sell based on the value add that we provide our very key customers. That's actually what it is. And we believe we deserve and get the value add that we provide in our products for the solutions of our customers. And -- but -- and we think it would drive us to 45%, it's a fairly, fairly decent way to get there.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. Amit, at this point, we're not updating our financial model. We're not updating our operating margin targets. We're very comfortable with 45%.
componenttext: Yes. Amit, at this point, we're not updating our financial model. We're not updating our operating margin targets. We're very comfortable with 45%.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. And if I just follow-up, yes, as I think of your gross margin guide for the upcoming quarter, you have a nice 6% uptick in sales, but you're talking about gross margins being flat, even though I think the headwind from wireless not being up a
componenttext: Fair enough. And if I just follow-up, yes, as I think of your gross margin guide for the upcoming quarter, you have a nice 6% uptick in sales, but you're talking about gross margins being flat, even though I think the headwind from wireless not being up as much should be a benefit. And last year, I think your gross margin was up like 40, 50 basis points in July. Why can't we see the same level of leverage given mix might be better this July versus last July?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, we kind of give you what we see. We hate to misforecast, guys, as you probably know. So we kind of give you something that we're pretty -- very comfortable with, and we are very comfortable at the midpoint of 63%, which you're right, we achieved it
componenttext: Well, we kind of give you what we see. We hate to misforecast, guys, as you probably know. So we kind of give you something that we're pretty -- very comfortable with, and we are very comfortable at the midpoint of 63%, which you're right, we achieved it last quarter.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, and Amit, I think we're going to be able to sustain in and around that number. I think you're right. There's some wireless mix that's slightly a headwind. We've also worked through a lot of the Broadcom synergies and the benefits we've received there
componenttext: Yes, and Amit, I think we're going to be able to sustain in and around that number. I think you're right. There's some wireless mix that's slightly a headwind. We've also worked through a lot of the Broadcom synergies and the benefits we've received there, but I think we plan to sustain that going forward.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Toshiya Hari with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Toshiya Hari with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: I had a question on the long-term revenue growth target. Obviously, you guys are committed to the mid-single-digit target that you put out a couple of quarters ago, but as you pointed out, you grew 18% in the April quarter. If we take the midpoint of your
componenttext: I had a question on the long-term revenue growth target. Obviously, you guys are committed to the mid-single-digit target that you put out a couple of quarters ago, but as you pointed out, you grew 18% in the April quarter. If we take the midpoint of your July quarter guide, I think you guys have the quarter growing about 17%. I realize the growth rate in enterprise, for example, is not necessarily sustainable, but what prevents you from raising the target to, say, high single digits on a long-term basis?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: On a long-term basis, no, because don't forget, the characteristics of our product lines, all 18 of them, even the 19th one, eventually, the Brocade, are -- they are very sustainable. That's the single most important criteria, sustainable franchises. I me
componenttext: On a long-term basis, no, because don't forget, the characteristics of our product lines, all 18 of them, even the 19th one, eventually, the Brocade, are -- they are very sustainable. That's the single most important criteria, sustainable franchises. I mean, they deliver value added and they keep delivering it generation after generation. They're not there to grow like weeds. They're not. And -- but they grew like GDP, pretty much, economic growth. We've  [ an adder ] for the fact that each generation provides further value added, which entitles us to have slight premium but not much, and hence, it's mid-single digits, which is GDP but plus that slight premium. No more than that. And that is, long term, the sustainable basis because it's the nature of the products we invest in, the nature of our business model. What you see now, I think, is a short-term event, which has driven the 18% -- 17%, 18% that you mentioned year-on-year in Q2 from last year is driven by 2 parts, is my view on this whole matter. One is wireless. The Q2 of a year ago, it's not because that Q2 this year is strong as much as the Q2 a year ago in wireless was unusually weak for good reasons, many of which I will not go into but you all know that. And this quarter, it's more of a normal Q2, perhaps somewhat buttressed by a strong launch of our big Korean customer. But it's kind of stronger than we expected, as I mentioned. So there's -- a big part of that double-digit growth is wireless growth driving it, and that's 30% of our total revenues, approximately. So if it grows a lot, it has that impact. And the second part of it is on infrastructure, our business in wired, industrial and enterprise storage, this year, '17 business is just strong. The tide just rose, and I think that's the other part that drove this double-digit growth. But you don't see that every year. In fact, I think this year is fairly unusually strong for infrastructure, apart from wireless infrastructure itself. So that combination is what creates this 18% growth. I would not, for a second, like you guys to think -- believe that this is something we will sustain for the next 5 years. What we feel comfortable we can sustain for the next 5 years is what we had said before and will continue to deliver, hopefully, over the next 5, 10 years, which is mid-single-digit growth on average year after year.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. And then as my follow-up, I just wanted to ask a follow-up question on M&A, and I realize the topic can be a little bit sensitive here. But Hock, you told us to not believe everything we read in the papers. Is it okay for us to walk away thi
componenttext: Okay. Got it. And then as my follow-up, I just wanted to ask a follow-up question on M&A, and I realize the topic can be a little bit sensitive here. But Hock, you told us to not believe everything we read in the papers. Is it okay for us to walk away thinking that you're not making the bids for that specific asset or -- again, I think as the gentleman asked the question before...

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Let me reiterate, please do not believe everything you read, and we do not comment on any rumors and pure speculation in the headline. But we continue to focus on our franchise stable business model. We have lots of free cash flow.
componenttext: Let me reiterate, please do not believe everything you read, and we do not comment on any rumors and pure speculation in the headline. But we continue to focus on our franchise stable business model. We have lots of free cash flow.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Harlan Sur with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Harlan Sur with JPMorgan.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: On the topic of free cash flow, you guys generated 32% free cash flow margins. But if I normalize for your target of 3% CapEx, you guys actually did 35% free cash flow margins, which is your target model. But I'm wondering, despite the great cash generati
componenttext: On the topic of free cash flow, you guys generated 32% free cash flow margins. But if I normalize for your target of 3% CapEx, you guys actually did 35% free cash flow margins, which is your target model. But I'm wondering, despite the great cash generation, do you guys still have some restructuring, acquisition-related cash charges which would imply that the normalized free cash flow, even now, is better than what you printed? And maybe if you guys could quantify some of those cash restructuring charges.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Take it.
componenttext: Take it.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. No, you're right. You're doing your math absolutely right. The company -- I mean, you're taking into account the elevated CapEx for mostly the campus investments we're making that you're aware of and some incremental restructuring charges, and f
componenttext: Yes, yes. No, you're right. You're doing your math absolutely right. The company -- I mean, you're taking into account the elevated CapEx for mostly the campus investments we're making that you're aware of and some incremental restructuring charges, and frankly, some working capital headwinds as the business continues to grow. You'll quickly get to 35%, which is where we want to be. And obviously, we got to continue to put up those numbers going forward. But based on where we see revenues and the gross margins and operating expenses that we outlined for you, we think that's achievable.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Great. And then for my follow-up question within enterprise storage. You guys have got a leadership position in server RAID and SaaS controller solutions, and typically, these products tend to track server shipments. So given Intel's Skylake server CPU la
componenttext: Great. And then for my follow-up question within enterprise storage. You guys have got a leadership position in server RAID and SaaS controller solutions, and typically, these products tend to track server shipments. So given Intel's Skylake server CPU launch and you've got AMD's EPIC server CPU launch, both I think which are ramping now, is this contributing to the growth here in the July quarter and maybe through the second half of this calendar year?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Not in the quarter we just ended, Q2, nor necessarily much in the July quarter, Q3. But certainly, we expect Purley, which is the generation you are talking about for Intel, launching Skylake, the Purley generation in storage will start to ramp up, you're
componenttext: Not in the quarter we just ended, Q2, nor necessarily much in the July quarter, Q3. But certainly, we expect Purley, which is the generation you are talking about for Intel, launching Skylake, the Purley generation in storage will start to ramp up, you're right, back half of this calendar year, really back half of this calendar year.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: And our next question goes the line of John Pitzer with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question goes the line of John Pitzer with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Hock, I wanted to talk a little bit about the wired results just for the April quarter. There's a lot of different businesses inside of wired, but the 3% year-over-year growth rate, I think, is kind of the slowest growth rate that we've seen since the fin
componenttext: Hock, I wanted to talk a little bit about the wired results just for the April quarter. There's a lot of different businesses inside of wired, but the 3% year-over-year growth rate, I think, is kind of the slowest growth rate that we've seen since the financial crisis. And so I'm just curious if you could give us a little of bit color as to what actually happened in the April quarter, where there was strength and where there might have been some relative weakness. And then as you think about sort of the re-acceleration into July, maybe some color around segments within wired would be helpful as well.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Wow, that's interesting, very confusing question, but let me try somewhat. And for the rest, I might have to take it offline another time because there are a lot of moving parts. And you're correct, in our wired segment, which represents 50% of revenue, w
componenttext: Wow, that's interesting, very confusing question, but let me try somewhat. And for the rest, I might have to take it offline another time because there are a lot of moving parts. And you're correct, in our wired segment, which represents 50% of revenue, we throw in the kitchen sink. Not really. All related to wired. There is actually a couple of chunks on broadband, which is broadband access, carrier access as well as CPE set-top box. And in Q2, those were not that strong, obviously. It starts ramping up seasonally Q3, Q4 -- or Q3 to Q4. So there is that effect that is not that strong. And year-on-year, a year ago -- a year ago, if you recall, that was the Summer Olympics, so we're comparing against the Summer Olympics, which will make it tough. And in Q3, Q4, that's post-Summer Olympics of last year, so it begins to look very good, which is what accelerates this in the second half. In switching and routing, no, we continue to feel very, very good. Whether it's in ASIC or merchant silicon, offtake delivery shipments continue to hit all-time high in those 2 segments. I hope that gives you enough. And then third thing that messes it up is we have building-block products like [ fines, retirements, ] which are more are unique to the designs that have been used, as well as fiber optics, which has gone through very interesting gyrations and cycles. That may mess up the number. But the 2 broadest area, broadband compared to a year ago is a hard compare because of Summer Olympics; but switching and routing, being as it may, continues to be a very, very strong franchise, whether it's in the form of an ASIC or in the form of merchant silicon, even though they are both selling into very different end users.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then, Hock, maybe for my follow up, on the ASIC side, I sort of have a general question. You've always had a strong switching/routing ASIC business. It's my understanding you're also doing ASICs for things like SSD controllers and perh
componenttext: That's helpful. And then, Hock, maybe for my follow up, on the ASIC side, I sort of have a general question. You've always had a strong switching/routing ASIC business. It's my understanding you're also doing ASICs for things like SSD controllers and perhaps the things like inference or deep learning. I'm just kind of curious, how do you think about the ASIC IP that Broadcom has? And would you consider that a franchise? And is it leverageable into areas beyond just switching and routing?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Oh, yes. You hit it right on. We do, do deep-learning ASICs. That means customized deep learning chips for specific customers. We do that because we have all the IP and hardware needed. Keep in mind, I believe deep learning is very much as much a software
componenttext: Oh, yes. You hit it right on. We do, do deep-learning ASICs. That means customized deep learning chips for specific customers. We do that because we have all the IP and hardware needed. Keep in mind, I believe deep learning is very much as much a software play much more than a hardware play. But we're happy to enable that for specific large customers in ASICs with customized hardware, which we do even right now, and retraining or inference. But we do that. Then on SSD controllers, yes, we do a huge amount of SSD controllers, relatively speaking, for -- basically, for enterprises only. Large enterprises. But they're all parked in our enterprise storage business. They're not parked in our wired business. And that business is doing very well, as you probably can gather today.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Stacy Rasgon with Bernstein Research.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Stacy Rasgon with Bernstein Research.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: First, I wanted to ask about the cash flow. So again, we can see the margins are bumping up, if you normalize, close to 35%. What about the payout ratio? So the payout ratio is still running around [ 5% ]. We're not close to 50%. What's stopping you from
componenttext:
First, I wanted to ask about the cash flow. So again, we can see the margins are bumping up, if you normalize, close to 35%. What about the payout ratio? So the payout ratio is still running around [ 5% ]. We're not close to 50%. What's stopping you from bringing it closer to 50% earlier? What's the trajectory that we should be thinking about for you. 
[Audio Gap] 
that targeted payout ratio?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. Hey, Stacy. I think we reiterated a couple quarters back when we put in place the updated financial policies that we're going to evaluate that once a year at the end of our fiscal year, so that will be in October-November timeframe. We're going to lo
componenttext: Yes. Hey, Stacy. I think we reiterated a couple quarters back when we put in place the updated financial policies that we're going to evaluate that once a year at the end of our fiscal year, so that will be in October-November timeframe. We're going to look back over our last fiscal year, look at that cash flow generation, look at the sustainability of the businesses that we're focused on and then make an assessment, obviously with the board's approval, around a recommendation. But what I want to reiterate is you're right, as we continue to perform, if we maintain, which we plan to do, our 50% payout, then that's going to lead to, obviously, an increase and potentially, a substantial increase in the dividend come the end of the year.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Got it. For my follow-up, I don't want to beat a dead horse, but can you refresh us on your definition of a franchise? What are the characteristics of a business that meets that definition? And frankly, would it be possible for a NAND flash business to qu
componenttext: Got it. For my follow-up, I don't want to beat a dead horse, but can you refresh us on your definition of a franchise? What are the characteristics of a business that meets that definition? And frankly, would it be possible for a NAND flash business to qualify as a franchise under your definition?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good try. Okay, let me give our definition a franchise, which is very open, and I'm glad you asked, give me a chance to repeat the mantra. No, a franchise basically is a -- we do only components, semiconductor components, and it's just components broadly,
componenttext: Good try. Okay, let me give our definition a franchise, which is very open, and I'm glad you asked, give me a chance to repeat the mantra. No, a franchise basically is a -- we do only components, semiconductor components, and it's just components broadly, is simply that it operates -- that product line operates in a niche. It doesn't have to be mass market. Most times, it's a niche. It's a niche where the markets are -- have been established and will likely to continue to be established for the foreseeable future. So we must have established end markets that are sustainable, one. And in that niche, in that market, we are the market leader. And more than the market leader, especially because when we are -- the reason for us being the market leader, we are the technology leader. We have to have the IP, we have to have the technology and the capability to continue to lead in that particular market. And the third, there's nothing financial about it. The financial is a fallout, a corollary fallout from those key criteria. And each of our 18 product lines meet those criteria. It's -- you make your own call whether NAND meets that criteria.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of  Ambrish Srivastava with BMO.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of  Ambrish Srivastava with BMO.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: I wanted to go back to your wired franchise, Hock. You talked about -- and this is a follow-up to John's -- John Pitzer's question. With regard to newer areas and of it in the umbrella of the 5% that you've articulated for the company quite well over the
componenttext: I wanted to go back to your wired franchise, Hock. You talked about -- and this is a follow-up to John's -- John Pitzer's question. With regard to newer areas and of it in the umbrella of the 5% that you've articulated for the company quite well over the last couple of years, is there something that is a one-off that you've done? Or do you see this is a broader volume with multiple customers as we go through the year and next year?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017

componenttext: Would you repeat that part? I must have missed some part in your question. If you [ could ]?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, the deep learning. Sorry, the deep learning ASIC that you are rolling out, is it a one-off for one customer or do see this expanding to multiple customers?
componenttext: Yes, the deep learning. Sorry, the deep learning ASIC that you are rolling out, is it a one-off for one customer or do see this expanding to multiple customers?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: It's an -- that deep learning product we're doing for multiple customers today are all customized solutions, hardware solutions on our side. They're not software-based solutions. We do -- we're -- it falls into our ASIC category. And we have all kinds of
componenttext: It's an -- that deep learning product we're doing for multiple customers today are all customized solutions, hardware solutions on our side. They're not software-based solutions. We do -- we're -- it falls into our ASIC category. And we have all kinds of intellectual property, all largely hardware based like SerDes -- much more than SerDes, memories, you name it, all kinds of stuff that goes into training and inference on a deep learning chip. We have all that IP, but we're only doing hardware. We're not -- make no pretensions to try and to make it a full solution. So it's an ASIC solution, and it covers multiple customers and it probably covers multiple generations going forward, but it's really simply an ASIC solution.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017

componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Srini Pajjuri with Macquarie Securities.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Hock, I just want to ask a clarifying question to the previous answer. Some of your peers are putting this market opportunity at close to $30 billion. I just want to hear your thoughts of how big the ASIC opportunity for deep learning in  your opinion is,
componenttext: Hock, I just want to ask a clarifying question to the previous answer. Some of your peers are putting this market opportunity at close to $30 billion. I just want to hear your thoughts of how big the ASIC opportunity for deep learning in  your opinion is, if you take maybe a 3-year view on this.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: I have no clue, to be honest. Seriously, no. It is -- our franchise here is the intellectual property capability we have of implementing silicon solutions that does deep learning. We could just as well have the IP implemented to do high-performance comput
componenttext: I have no clue, to be honest. Seriously, no. It is -- our franchise here is the intellectual property capability we have of implementing silicon solutions that does deep learning. We could just as well have the IP implemented to do high-performance computing or, as we do now a lot, switching and routing. This, we do in deep learning. And for us, deep learning is not seen necessarily as a franchise. It's our ASIC capability that is a franchise.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then, I know you said you don't want to comment on your competitors' trash talk, but if you could maybe comment on -- in terms of your BAW performance, I think historically, the reason you had such a significant share was you had a significant
componenttext: Got it. And then, I know you said you don't want to comment on your competitors' trash talk, but if you could maybe comment on -- in terms of your BAW performance, I think historically, the reason you had such a significant share was you had a significant performance advantage over your competitors. I'm just trying to understand if some of your peers are closing that gap or at least narrowing the gap. And as we look out to the next couple of years, I just want to understand how much advantage you'll still have in BAW.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Remember my definition of a sustainable franchise? We don't stop investing. I mean, contrary to myths out there, we actually -- every time we pick a particular product line as our core product lines, as one of the 18, we invest as much as we have to, to m
componenttext: Remember my definition of a sustainable franchise? We don't stop investing. I mean, contrary to myths out there, we actually -- every time we pick a particular product line as our core product lines, as one of the 18, we invest as much as we have to, to maintain, if not lengthen, our lead. No different here. We don't stay put at the generation of last year or 2 years ago or 3 years ago. We continue to invest. The lead, to be direct with you, never closes, and that's the key part of our model. We will invest. And given that your market -- we are the market leader in that niche, we can afford to out-invest anyone out there. We -- in R&D, for this entire company, as you noticed that, in totality, some of it pops up in cost of sales or product engineering as we bring it to production. The rest of it in R&D. We spend on product development in this company, every year, $3 billion. And that's not counting CapEx. $3 billion. And we are very, very conscious of the fact that we have to maintain, if not, even increase that level of spending where we need to in specific areas to ensure that we are the leader both in technology, which leads to market leader. So not that easy to narrow the lead in terms of coming to compete with us.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Hock, if I could -- I wanted to follow-up on your earlier comments on the storage -- your storage business and your guidance for stable demand beginning in this fiscal third quarter. I was wondering, if we're looking back earlier this year, when the stora
componenttext: Hock, if I could -- I wanted to follow-up on your earlier comments on the storage -- your storage business and your guidance for stable demand beginning in this fiscal third quarter. I was wondering, if we're looking back earlier this year, when the storage business was seeing better demand because of some of the shortages in NAND flash for SSDs, I was wondering if your customers are providing you much commentary on whether the current hard drive demand is in line with broader demand, or if there's still some element of NAND SSD shortages that are helping hard drive demand.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: This is a very hard market to predict at this point because there are a lot of multiple dynamics going on in terms of -- it's not just about flash demand being -- reaching very high levels, which is driving everything else. Probably is, but in -- that was
componenttext: This is a very hard market to predict at this point because there are a lot of multiple dynamics going on in terms of -- it's not just about flash demand being -- reaching very high levels, which is driving everything else. Probably is, but in -- that was probably late '16, early '17. Today, I guess, all this big -- all these increased prices in memory, whether DRAM, flash, is -- not hard drives as much as DRAM and flash, is leading to careful spending by enterprises and operators and cloud guys and data center guys. They all have been very careful. So suddenly, you have -- so demand, that is there. That is needed, but people are not spending. And you go -- you will have these stop and starts going on. So it's all very confusing is what I'm trying to come -- to get on. And I'm not sure we have as much -- any better -- or we have any better visibility than even our customers or our customers have better visibility on -- than us, for that matter. It's just very confusing. And all we can see is that demand has flattened out for our products, be they SSDs or be they -- SSD flash controllers, I should clarify, or be they components, rechannels and [ preempts ] for hard disk drive. All we see is that a quarter ago, we were saying, better -- got to be careful about Q3. Well, Q2 has gone -- come and gone. Q2 was good. Q3 continues to look good. But then, I'm going -- do you want to say Q4 may cave? Who knows. We're still booking Q4, but it may not be as strong. And a big part of that uncertainty lies in the fact that there's more than just simply a shortage of flash or DRAMs that's creating this uncertainty. I think it's much more than that. It's also the change in spending patterns, even in the short term, of data center guys, cloud guys and enterprises because of higher memory prices.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, I appreciate those considerations. And I just have a quick follow-up. For your wireless connectivity business, I know much of that revenue is still driven by mobile-type applications, but I was wondering how meaningful is your exposure to enterprise
componenttext: Okay, I appreciate those considerations. And I just have a quick follow-up. For your wireless connectivity business, I know much of that revenue is still driven by mobile-type applications, but I was wondering how meaningful is your exposure to enterprise-type access points today. And any exposure in like, automotive hotspots potentially going forward?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: They are -- I guess, the best way to describe it is broadband carrier access are increasingly -- even set-top box -- which includes set-top box, both CPE, that is, as well as central office are starting to sprout WiFi as another means. You have GPON, EPON
componenttext: They are -- I guess, the best way to describe it is broadband carrier access are increasingly -- even set-top box -- which includes set-top box, both CPE, that is, as well as central office are starting to sprout WiFi as another means. You have GPON, EPON, you have DSL, VDSL, now WiFi into the picture. So it's all good. And we are very, very well positioned in all this, including next generation. So it is giving us more content to be -- put it this way, at every access point, which may help the growth. But it's still not as big, by the way, as the phone, by comparison, the volume. But it's a decent amount of volume and it gives us a very sustainable franchise in this area as well.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Broadcom Limited's Second Quarter Fiscal Year 2017 Financial Results Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Ashish Saran, Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, si
componenttext:
Welcome to Broadcom Limited's Second Quarter Fiscal Year 2017 Financial Results Conference Call. 
At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Ashish Saran, Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator, and good afternoon, everyone. Joining me today are Hock Tan, President and CEO; and Tom Krause, Chief Financial Officer of Broadcom Limited. After market close today, Broadcom distributed a press release and financial tables describ
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and good afternoon, everyone. Joining me today are Hock Tan, President and CEO; and Tom Krause, Chief Financial Officer of Broadcom Limited. 
After market close today, Broadcom distributed a press release and financial tables describing our financial performance for the second quarter of fiscal year 2017. If you did not receive a copy, you may obtain the information from the Investors section of Broadcom's website at www.broadcom.com.
This conference call is being webcast live, and a recording will be available via telephone playback for 1 week. It will also be archived in the Investors section of our website at broadcom.com. 
During the prepared comments section of this call, Hock and Tom will be providing details of our second quarter fiscal year 2017 results, background to our third quarter fiscal year 2017 outlook and some commentary regarding the business environment. We will take questions after the end of our prepared comments.
In addition to U.S. GAAP reporting, Broadcom reports certain financial measures on a non-GAAP basis. A reconciliation between GAAP and non-GAAP measures is included in the tables attached to today's press release. Comments made during today's call will primarily refer to our non-GAAP financial results. Please refer to our press release today and our recent filings with the SEC for information on the specific risk factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statements made on this call.
At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Hock Tan. Hock?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ashish. Good afternoon, everyone. I'm actually quite pleased with our performance for the second fiscal quarter, with solid contributions from a broad number of our franchises. We delivered strong financial results with revenue, gross margin
componenttext:
Thank you, Ashish. Good afternoon, everyone. 
I'm actually quite pleased with our performance for the second fiscal quarter, with solid contributions from a broad number of our franchises. We delivered strong financial results with revenue, gross margin and earnings per share all above the top line -- top end of our guidance.
Second quarter revenue of $4.2 billion grew 1% sequentially and 18% year-on-year. The seasonal sequential decline in our wireless segment was less than expected and more than offset by contributions from all other segments. All segments, even wireless, delivered year-on-year revenue growth. On the income front, earnings per share were $3.69, growing by 2% sequentially and 46% year-on-year.
Let me now turn to the discussion of our results by segment. Starting with wired, our largest segment. In the second quarter, wired revenue was very stable at $2.1 billion, growing 1% sequentially and 3% year-on-year. The wired segment represented 50% of our total revenue. Wired continue to remain a very consistent end market and perform in line with expectations. 
As you may recall in the preceding quarter, wired revenue included approximately $60 million of revenue related to the assignment of certain manufacturer's right to a customer. This did not repeat in the second quarter. However, we were able to more than make up for this amount with growth from enterprise networking and the start of a seasonal increase in demand for our broadband access and set-top box products. 
Turning to the third fiscal quarter. Though we expect seasonal strength in broadband and sustained cloud data center spend, and consistent with this outlook, we expect wired revenue growth to accelerate into mid-single digits, sequentially. 
Moving on to wireless. Second quarter wireless revenue was $1.15 billion, declining by 2% sequentially but growing 45% year-on-year. Wireless -- the wireless segment represented 28% of our total revenue. The low single-digit sequential decline in revenue was better than expected due to stronger-than-anticipated end-market demand. The sequential decline was driven by the bottom of the annual product cycle transition at our major North American customer, offset by the ramp of the next-generation phone at our large Korean smartphone customer. Generation-to-generation, we also benefited from a significant increase in Broadcom's cellular and WiFi connectivity content.
Moving on now to the third quarter. We expect to see the beginning of the second half seasonal growth in our wireless segment revenue. We expect this growth to be driven by the start of a ramp from a north -- large North American smartphone customer as they transition to their next-generation platform. On top of this, we are also expecting a substantial increase in our total dollar content from the 8 Broadcom products we will be supplying into this new platform. The initial ramp of this next-generation platform, however, appears slower this year compared to prior years, but we believe this will likely accelerate in our fourth quarter. 
Our third fiscal quarter outlook reflects this expectation. And notwithstanding the 40% content growth, we project sequential growth in our wireless revenue to only approach double digits on a percentage basis. This outlook also reflects an expected decline in shipments to our large Korean smartphone customer. 
Let me now turn to enterprise storage. In the second quarter, enterprise storage revenue was $712 million, growing 1% sequentially and 36% year-on-year. Storage segment represented 17% of our total revenue. Surprisingly, this segment continued to hold up and perform as expected. Hard disk drive and custom SSD shipments grew while SaaS and RAID sustained, offset by a seasonal decline in Fibre Channel shipments. 
During our previous earnings call, we expressed a cautionary tone around enterprise storage for the third quarter. However, we continue to see stability and, most of all, sustained bookings. We expect storage revenue to grow in the low single digits sequentially into the third quarter.
And finally, our last segment, industrial. In the second quarter, the industrial segment revenue was $223 million, growing by 24% sequentially, much better than expected primarily due to higher IP, intellectual property that is, licensing revenue from a large deal we closed in the quarter. Industrial revenue grew 23% year-on-year and represented 5% of our total revenue. Resales of our industrial products continued to trend up very firmly in the second quarter and we expect this to continue to be strong into the next quarter. As we look to the third quarter, we expect industrial revenue to grow in the mid-single digits, sequentially.
So in summary, demand in the second quarter, which is historically our weakest seasonal quarter, was stronger than expected. For the third fiscal quarter, end markets in wired, enterprise, storage and industrial continue to be strong, while wireless turns around and starts a slower-than-usual seasonal second half ramp, although we do expect it to accelerate dramatically in the fourth quarter. This leads to a projection of consolidated revenue growth of around 6% sequentially for the third quarter. 
With that, let me turn the call over to Tom for a more detailed review of our second quarter financials and third quarter outlook.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Hock, and good afternoon, everyone. My comments today will focus primarily on our non-GAAP results from continuing operations, unless otherwise specifically noted. The reconciliation of our GAAP to non-GAAP data is included with the earnings re
componenttext:
Thank you, Hock, and good afternoon, everyone. My comments today will focus primarily on our non-GAAP results from continuing operations, unless otherwise specifically noted. The reconciliation of our GAAP to non-GAAP data is included with the earnings release issued today and is also available on our website at broadcom.com.
[Audio Gap] 
for the second quarter, starting with revenue of $4.2 billion, which grew by 1% sequentially. Year-on-year growth for the second quarter revenue was 18%, which I would note is -- continues to be well ahead of our long-term growth rate targets of mid-single digits. Foxconn was the only greater-than-10% direct customer in the second fiscal quarter.
Our second quarter gross margins from continuing operations was 63.1%, 70 basis points higher than our prior quarter and 110 basis points above the midpoint of guidance. The improvement in gross margin's primarily due to lower revenue and better-than-expected IP licensing revenue within our industrial and other segment. I would note we do expect to be able to sustain these gross margins going forward.
Turning to operating expenses. R&D expenses were $677 million and SG&A expenses were $122 million, totaling $799 million or 19% of net revenue for the second quarter. This is slightly higher than guidance as we accrued for a larger projected annual bonus compensation expense driven by better-than-expected operating income. As I mentioned last quarter, we are comfortable at this relative level of operating expense given our current portfolio of businesses.
Operating income from continuing operations for the quarter was $1.85 billion and represented 44.1% of net revenue. We now have line of sight to achieving our long-term operating margin target of 45%. 
Provision for taxes came in at $78 million, slightly above our guidance. This is primarily due to higher-than-expected net income. 
Second quarter interest expense was $112 million; and other income, net, was $3 million. 
Second quarter net income was $1.67 billion, and earnings per diluted share was $3.69. Our share-based compensation expense in the second quarter was $216 million.
Moving on to the balance sheet. Our days sales outstanding were 45 days, an increase of 2 days from the prior quarter due to a reduction in linearity of revenue in the quarter. Our inventory ended at $1.31 billion, a decrease of $25 million from the beginning of the quarter. 
We generated $1.58 billion in operational cash flow, which does include the impact of an increase in working capital. 
Expenditures on classic Broadcom restructuring and integration activities continues to decline, as expected, as we expended approximately by $15 million -- $50 million in cash on these activities in the second quarter.
Free cash flow in the second quarter was $1.33 billion or 32% of net revenue. I would note, we are making very good progress towards our long-term target of 35%. 
Capital expenditure in the second quarter was $256 million or 6.1% of net revenue. As a reminder, we do expect our long-term CapEx to decline to about 3% of net revenue.
A total of $437 million in cash was spent on company dividend partnership distribution payments in the second quarter. 
We ended the second quarter with a cash and short-term investments balance of $4.45 billion. Our cash balance is running at elevated levels, which we expect will continue through the third quarter in anticipation of closing the pending acquisition of Brocade.
Now let me turn to our non-GAAP guidance for the third quarter of fiscal year 2017. This guidance reflects our current assessment of business conditions, and we do not intend to update this guidance. This guidance is for results from continuing operations only.
Net revenue is expected to be $4.45 billion, plus or minus $75 million. Gross margins is expected to be 63%, plus or minus 1 percentage point. Operating expenses are estimated to be approximately $787 million. Our tax provision is forecasted to be approximately $86 million. Net interest expense and other is expected to be approximately $100 million. Note this reflects anticipated interest expense on our long-term debt of $112 million, offset largely by other income, including interest earned on our cash balance. The diluted share count forecast is for 456 million shares. Share-based compensation expense will be approximately $255 million. Capital expenditures will be approximately $240 million.
As you will have seen, our board has declared a dividend of $1.02 per share to be paid later in this fiscal -- third fiscal quarter. 
We are looking forward to completing the acquisition of Brocade, which is proceeding as planned. And subject to the satisfaction of the remaining closing conditions, we presently expect to close this transaction on or about July 31, 2017.
That concludes my prepared remarks. Operator, please open up the call for questions.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: It's timing. I think it's timing. Last year, the similar ramp was earlier in Q -- it was stronger in Q3, probably because it was earlier. And here, the initial volume in our fiscal Q3 was smaller, made up with content on our side. But definitely, Q4 is fo
componenttext: It's timing. I think it's timing. Last year, the similar ramp was earlier in Q -- it was stronger in Q3, probably because it was earlier. And here, the initial volume in our fiscal Q3 was smaller, made up with content on our side. But definitely, Q4 is forecast to be larger.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017

componenttext: And then you mentioned this on the storage side. You had some conservatism on the second half and you're seeing growth. Maybe you can just talk about what you're seeing on the storage side that is growing, and then what are you seeing -- I think your hard drives, where you're most concerned, what's making you feel better about that market?

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, it's growing, as we mentioned, pretty much single digits -- low single digits. I would say it's at a high, elevated level and kind of staying there for now in Q3. Q4 of course, as we expressed in a cautionary manner, is a whole new game. And visibil
componenttext: Well, it's growing, as we mentioned, pretty much single digits -- low single digits. I would say it's at a high, elevated level and kind of staying there for now in Q3. Q4 of course, as we expressed in a cautionary manner, is a whole new game. And visibility is -- we obviously are not booking everything in Q4 yet, but we've pretty much booked Q3.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017

componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of the Vivek Arya with Bank of America.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: For my first question, Hock, can you please address these recent media reports about the potentially large bid for Toshiba's assets? I realize that details are not public, but there is a very large amount of money involved and I think investors are keen t
componenttext: For my first question, Hock, can you please address these recent media reports about the potentially large bid for Toshiba's assets? I realize that details are not public, but there is a very large amount of money involved and I think investors are keen to know how you are thinking about it conceptually and whether you are still committed to being disciplined around maintaining your free cash flow returns and not taking big technology risks when you consider M&A.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: We are very committed to our business model of only having franchises, very much so. And as I mentioned, all 18 of product lines are product franchises in connectivity solutions. We are also very committed to not only those franchises but generating lots
componenttext: We are very committed to our business model of only having franchises, very much so. And as I mentioned, all 18 of product lines are product franchises in connectivity solutions. We are also very committed to not only those franchises but generating lots and lots of free cash flow, which we -- half of which we will return to shareholders. All that [ part of the ] model, no change. Bottom line, don't believe everything you read out there, please.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: I see. And then secondly, on the wireless business, I think you gave some good color for Q3. Just one question on Q4 and then maybe longer term. Q4, when I look at the last 5 years, the median sort of sequential growth has been close to 30%. So is that th
componenttext: I see. And then secondly, on the wireless business, I think you gave some good color for Q3. Just one question on Q4 and then maybe longer term. Q4, when I look at the last 5 years, the median sort of sequential growth has been close to 30%. So is that the kind of level that you're thinking about this year or maybe even better, given the delayed shipments of those phones and the higher content you suggested? And then longer term on that same wireless theme, I think one of your competitors, Qorvo, recently outlined some plans to perhaps take some share at your large customer with a higher-band PAD. And I wanted to see how secure you think your competitive position is on next year's phone models.

headline: Broadcom Limited, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Boy, that's a lot of questions and content. Let's start with the serious one. We don't forecast beyond one quarter. Bad practice, frankly, because we could be very sadly wrong. But obviously, what we are also saying is from the limited visibility we see,
componenttext: Boy, that's a lot of questions and content. Let's start with the serious one. We don't forecast beyond one quarter. Bad practice, frankly, because we could be very sadly wrong. But obviously, what we are also saying is from the limited visibility we see, we see the ramp beginning in our fiscal Q3, which, as you know, is an off-calendar ramp by 1 month, July. So we capture a part of that ramp, I believe -- we believe, a small part. And we expect to capture the substantial part of that ramp in Q4. But keep in mind [ comes ] always when you compare year-on-year, we have different content levels from a year ago, substantially, as I pointed out. So that might kind of confuse the numbers somewhat. But enough -- suffice to say, Q3, as we outlined since the beginning of the ramp, may not be the same level of ramp if you compare to a year ago for a couple of reasons I mentioned. But we also see Q4 to even ramp up even more substantially, obviously, because if Q3 is slower, it's more than likely Q4 in any product ramp will just show a stronger quarter compared to Q3. So that's it. But after -- the specifics, really, we're -- I'm not really at liberty to disclose it because we just don't go look that far out. As far as the trash talk you hear out there, seriously, we don't prefer to -- I prefer not to comment on that.
